clickable function function_register_new_user" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_register_new_user .collapse"> <h2>Handles registering a new user.</h2> <pre>register_new_user(string $user_login, string $user_email) : int | <a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$user_login</h4> <code>string</code><p>User's username for logging in</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$user_email</h4> <code>string</code><p>User's email address to send password and add</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>int</code><code><a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></code>Either user's ID or error on failure.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_register_post_status"></a><div class="element clickable function function_register_post_status" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_register_post_status .collapse"> <h2>Register a post status.</h2> <pre>register_post_status(string $post_status, array | string $args) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Do not use before init.</p> <p>A simple function for creating or modifying a post status based on the parameters given. The function will accept an array (second optional parameter), along with a string for the post status name.</p> <p>Optional $args contents:</p> <p>label - A descriptive name for the post status marked for translation. Defaults to $post_status. public - Whether posts of this status should be shown in the front end of the site. Defaults to true. exclude_from_search - Whether to exclude posts with this post status from search results. Defaults to false. show_in_admin_all_list - Whether to include posts in the edit listing for their post type show_in_admin_status_list - Show in the list of statuses with post counts at the top of the edit listings, e.g. All (12) | Published (9) | My Custom Status (2) ...</p> <p>Arguments prefixed with an _underscore shouldn't be used by plugins and themes.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Post.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Post</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>3.0.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$wp_post_statuses</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$post_status</h4> <code>string</code><p>Name of the post status.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><code>string</code><p>See above description.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_register_post_type"></a><div class="element clickable function function_register_post_type" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_register_post_type .collapse"> <h2>Register a post type.</h2> <pre>register_post_type(string $post_type, array | string $args) : object | <a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Do not use before init.</p> <p>A function for creating or modifying a post type based on the parameters given. The function will accept an array (second optional parameter), along with a string for the post type name.</p> <p>Optional $args contents:</p> <ul> <li>label - Name of the post type shown in the menu. Usually plural. If not set, labels['name'] will be used.</li> <li>labels - An array of labels for this post type. <ul> <li>If not set, post labels are inherited for non-hierarchical types and page labels for hierarchical ones.</li> <li>You can see accepted values in <a href="get_post_type_labels()">get_post_type_labels()</a>.</li> </ul></li> <li>description - A short descriptive summary of what the post type is. Defaults to blank.</li> <li>public - Whether a post type is intended for use publicly either via the admin interface or by front-end users. <ul> <li>Defaults to false.</li> <li>While the default settings of exclude_from_search, publicly_queryable, show_ui, and show_in_nav_menus are inherited from public, each does not rely on this relationship and controls a very specific intention.</li> </ul></li> <li>exclude_from_search - Whether to exclude posts with this post type from front end search results. <ul> <li>If not set, the the opposite of public's current value is used.</li> </ul></li> <li>publicly_queryable - Whether queries can be performed on the front end for the post type as part of parse_request(). <ul> <li>?post_type={post_type_key}</li> <li>?{post_type_key}={single_post_slug}</li> <li>?{post_type_query_var}={single_post_slug}</li> <li>If not set, the default is inherited from public.</li> </ul></li> <li>show_ui - Whether to generate a default UI for managing this post type in the admin. <ul> <li>If not set, the default is inherited from public.</li> </ul></li> <li>show_in_nav_menus - Makes this post type available for selection in navigation menus. <ul> <li>If not set, the default is inherited from public.</li> </ul></li> <li>show_in_menu - Where to show the post type in the admin menu. <ul> <li>If true, the post type is shown in its own top level menu.</li> <li>If false, no menu is shown</li> <li>If a string of an existing top level menu (eg. 'tools.php' or 'edit.php?post_type=page'), the post type will be placed as a sub menu of that.</li> <li>show_ui must be true.</li> <li>If not set, the default is inherited from show_ui</li> </ul></li> <li>show_in_admin_bar - Makes this post type available via the admin bar. <ul> <li>If not set, the default is inherited from show_in_menu</li> </ul></li> <li>menu_position - The position in the menu order the post type should appear. <ul> <li>show_in_menu must be true</li> <li>Defaults to null, which places it at the bottom of its area.</li> </ul></li> <li>menu_icon - The url to the icon to be used for this menu. Defaults to use the posts icon.</li> <li>capability_type - The string to use to build the read, edit, and delete capabilities. Defaults to 'post'. <ul> <li>May be passed as an array to allow for alternative plurals when using this argument as a base to construct the capabilities, e.g. array('story', 'stories').</li> </ul></li> <li>capabilities - Array of capabilities for this post type. <ul> <li>By default the capability_type is used as a base to construct capabilities.</li> <li>You can see accepted values in <a href="get_post_type_capabilities()">get_post_type_capabilities()</a>.</li> </ul></li> <li>map_meta_cap - Whether to use the internal default meta capability handling. Defaults to false.</li> <li>hierarchical - Whether the post type is hierarchical (e.g. page). Defaults to false.</li> <li>supports - An alias for calling add_post_type_support() directly. Defaults to title and editor. <ul> <li>See <a href="add_post_type_support()">add_post_type_support()</a> for documentation.</li> </ul></li> <li>register_meta_box_cb - Provide a callback function that will be called when setting up the meta boxes for the edit form. Do remove_meta_box() and add_meta_box() calls in the callback.</li> <li>taxonomies - An array of taxonomy identifiers that will be registered for the post type. <ul> <li>Default is no taxonomies.</li> <li>Taxonomies can be registered later with register_taxonomy() or register_taxonomy_for_object_type().</li> </ul></li> <li>has_archive - True to enable post type archives. Default is false. <ul> <li>Will generate the proper rewrite rules if rewrite is enabled.</li> </ul></li> <li>rewrite - Triggers the handling of rewrites for this post type. Defaults to true, using $post_type as slug. <ul> <li>To prevent rewrite, set to false.</li> <li>To specify rewrite rules, an array can be passed with any of these keys <ul> <li>'slug' => string Customize the permastruct slug. Defaults to $post_type key</li> <li>'with_front' => bool Should the permastruct be prepended with WP_Rewrite::$front. Defaults to true.</li> <li>'feeds' => bool Should a feed permastruct be built for this post type. Inherits default from has_archive.</li> <li>'pages' => bool Should the permastruct provide for pagination. Defaults to true.</li> <li>'ep_mask' => const Assign an endpoint mask. <ul> <li>If not specified and permalink_epmask is set, inherits from permalink_epmask.</li> <li>If not specified and permalink_epmask is not set, defaults to EP_PERMALINK</li> </ul></li> </ul></li> </ul></li> <li>query_var - Sets the query_var key for this post type. Defaults to $post_type key <ul> <li>If false, a post type cannot be loaded at ?{query_var}={post_slug}</li> <li>If specified as a string, the query ?{query_var_string}={post_slug} will be valid.</li> </ul></li> <li>can_export - Allows this post type to be exported. Defaults to true.</li> <li>delete_with_user - Whether to delete posts of this type when deleting a user. <ul> <li>If true, posts of this type belonging to the user will be moved to trash when then user is deleted.</li> <li>If false, posts of this type belonging to the user will <em>not</em> be trashed or deleted.</li> <li>If not set (the default), posts are trashed if post_type_supports('author'). Otherwise posts are not trashed or deleted.</li> </ul></li> <li>_builtin - true if this post type is a native or "built-in" post_type. THIS IS FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY!</li> <li>_edit_link - URL segement to use for edit link of this post type. THIS IS FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY!</li> </ul></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.9.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$wp_post_types</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$post_type</h4> <code>string</code><p>Post type key, must not exceed 20 characters</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><code>string</code><p>See optional args description above.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>object</code><code><a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></code>the registered post type object, or an error object</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_register_setting"></a><div class="element clickable function function_register_setting" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_register_setting .collapse"> <h2>Register a setting and its sanitization callback</h2> <pre>register_setting(string $option_group, string $option_name, \unknown_type $sanitize_callback) : \unknown</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$option_group</h4> <code>string</code><p>A settings group name. Should correspond to a whitelisted option key name. Default whitelisted option key names include "general," "discussion," and "reading," among others.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$option_name</h4> <code>string</code><p>The name of an option to sanitize and save.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$sanitize_callback</h4> <code>\unknown_type</code><p>A callback function that sanitizes the option's value.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"><code>\unknown</code></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_register_sidebar"></a><div class="element clickable function function_register_sidebar" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_register_sidebar .collapse"> <h2>Builds the definition for a single sidebar and returns the ID.</h2> <pre>register_sidebar(string | array $args) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The $args parameter takes either a string or an array with 'name' and 'id' contained in either usage. It will be noted that the values will be applied to all sidebars, so if creating more than one, it will be advised to allow for WordPress to create the defaults for you.</p> <p>Example for string would be</p> <pre><code>'name=whatever;id=whatever1'</code></pre> <p>and for the array it would be</p> <pre><code>array( 'name' => 'whatever', 'id' => 'whatever1')</code></pre> <p>.</p> <p>name - The name of the sidebar, which presumably the title which will be displayed. id - The unique identifier by which the sidebar will be called by. before_widget - The content that will prepended to the widgets when they are displayed. after_widget - The content that will be appended to the widgets when they are displayed. before_title - The content that will be prepended to the title when displayed. after_title - the content that will be appended to the title when displayed.</p> <p><em>Content</em> is assumed to be HTML and should be formatted as such, but doesn't have to be.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.2.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$wp_registered_sidebars</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>string</code><code>array</code><p>Builds Sidebar based off of 'name' and 'id' values</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>The sidebar id that was added.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_register_sidebar_widget"></a><div class="element clickable function function_register_sidebar_widget" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_register_sidebar_widget .collapse"> <h2>Register widget for sidebar with backwards compatibility.</h2> <pre>register_sidebar_widget(string | int $name, callback $output_callback, string $classname) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Allows $name to be an array that accepts either three elements to grab the first element and the third for the name or just uses the first element of the array for the name.</p> <p>Passes to <a href="wp_register_sidebar_widget()">wp_register_sidebar_widget()</a> after argument list and backwards compatibility is complete.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.2.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>deprecated</th> <td>2.8.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>deprecated</th> <td>Use wp_register_sidebar_widget()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\wp_register_sidebar_widget()</a></td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$name</h4> <code>string</code><code>int</code><p>Widget ID.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$output_callback</h4> <code>callback</code><p>Run when widget is called.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$classname</h4> <code>string</code><p>Classname widget option.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_register_sidebars"></a><div class="element clickable function function_register_sidebars" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_register_sidebars .collapse"> <h2>Creates multiple sidebars.</h2> <pre>register_sidebars(int $number, string | array $args) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>If you wanted to quickly create multiple sidebars for a theme or internally. This function will allow you to do so. If you don't pass the 'name' and/or 'id' in $args, then they will be built for you.</p> <p>The default for the name is "Sidebar #", with '#' being replaced with the number the sidebar is currently when greater than one. If first sidebar, the name will be just "Sidebar". The default for id is "sidebar-" followed by the number the sidebar creation is currently at. If the id is provided, and multiple sidebars are being defined, the id will have "-2" appended, and so on.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.2.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\register_sidebar()</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\parse_str()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\register_sidebar()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$number</h4> <code>int</code><p>Number of sidebars to create.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>string</code><code>array</code><p>Builds Sidebar based off of 'name' and 'id' values.</p> </div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_register_taxonomy"></a><div class="element clickable function function_register_taxonomy" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_register_taxonomy .collapse"> <h2>Create or modify a taxonomy object.</h2> <pre>register_taxonomy(string $taxonomy, array | string $object_type, array | string $args) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Do not use before init.</p> <p>A simple function for creating or modifying a taxonomy object based on the parameters given. The function will accept an array (third optional parameter), along with strings for the taxonomy name and another string for the object type.</p> <p>Nothing is returned, so expect error maybe or use taxonomy_exists() to check whether taxonomy exists.</p> <p>Optional $args contents:</p> <p>label - Name of the taxonomy shown in the menu. Usually plural. If not set, labels['name'] will be used.</p> <p>hierarchical - has some defined purpose at other parts of the API and is a boolean value.</p> <p>update_count_callback - works much like a hook, in that it will be called when the count is updated. Defaults to _update_post_term_count() for taxonomies attached to post types, which then confirms that the objects are published before counting them. Defaults to _update_generic_term_count() for taxonomies attached to other object types, such as links.</p> <p>rewrite - false to prevent rewrite, or array('slug'=>$slug) to customize permastruct; default will use $taxonomy as slug.</p> <p>query_var - false to prevent queries, or string to customize query var (?$query_var=$term); default will use $taxonomy as query var.</p> <p>public - If the taxonomy should be publicly queryable; //@TODO not implemented. defaults to true.</p> <p>show_ui - If the WordPress UI admin tags UI should apply to this taxonomy; defaults to public.</p> <p>show_in_nav_menus - true makes this taxonomy available for selection in navigation menus. Defaults to public.</p> <p>show_tagcloud - false to prevent the taxonomy being listed in the Tag Cloud Widget; defaults to show_ui which defaults to public.</p> <p>labels - An array of labels for this taxonomy. You can see accepted values in <a href="get_taxonomy_labels()">get_taxonomy_labels()</a>. By default tag labels are used for non-hierarchical types and category labels for hierarchical ones.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Taxonomy.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Taxonomy</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$wp_taxonomies</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$wp</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$taxonomy</h4> <code>string</code><p>Name of taxonomy object</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$object_type</h4> <code>array</code><code>string</code><p>Name of the object type for the taxonomy object.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><code>string</code><p>See above description for the two keys values.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_register_taxonomy_for_object_type"></a><div class="element clickable function function_register_taxonomy_for_object_type" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_register_taxonomy_for_object_type .collapse"> <h2>Add an already registered taxonomy to an object type.</h2> <pre>register_taxonomy_for_object_type(string $taxonomy, string $object_type) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Taxonomy.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Taxonomy</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>3.0.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_register_theme_directory"></a><div class="element clickable function function_register_theme_directory" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_register_theme_directory .collapse"> <h2>Register a directory that contains themes.</h2> <pre>register_theme_directory(string $directory) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.9.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$directory</h4> <code>string</code><p>Either the full filesystem path to a theme folder or a folder within WP_CONTENT_DIR</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"><code>bool</code></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_register_uninstall_hook"></a><div class="element clickable function function_register_uninstall_hook" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_register_uninstall_hook .collapse"> <h2>Set the uninstallation hook for a plugin.</h2> <pre>register_uninstall_hook(string $file, callback $callback) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Registers the uninstall hook that will be called when the user clicks on the uninstall link that calls for the plugin to uninstall itself. The link won't be active unless the plugin hooks into the action.</p> <p>The plugin should not run arbitrary code outside of functions, when registering the uninstall hook. In order to run using the hook, the plugin will have to be included, which means that any code laying outside of a function will be run during the uninstall process. The plugin should not hinder the uninstall process.</p> <p>If the plugin can not be written without running code within the plugin, then the plugin should create a file named 'uninstall.php' in the base plugin folder. This file will be called, if it exists, during the uninstall process bypassing the uninstall hook. The plugin, when using the 'uninstall.php' should always check for the 'WP_UNINSTALL_PLUGIN' constant, before executing.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$file</h4> <code>string</code> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$callback</h4> <code>callback</code><p>The callback to run when the hook is called. Must be a static method or function.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_register_widget"></a><div class="element clickable function function_register_widget" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_register_widget .collapse"> <h2>Register a widget</h2> <pre>register_widget(string $widget_class) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Registers a WP_Widget widget</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.8.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\WP_Widget</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\WP_Widget_Factory</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\WP_Widget_Factory</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$widget_class</h4> <code>string</code><p>The name of a class that extends WP_Widget</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_register_widget_control"></a><div class="element clickable function function_register_widget_control" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_register_widget_control .collapse"> <h2>Registers widget control callback for customizing options.</h2> <pre>register_widget_control(int | string $name, callback $control_callback, int $width, int $height) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Allows $name to be an array that accepts either three elements to grab the first element and the third for the name or just uses the first element of the array for the name.</p> <p>Passes to <a href="wp_register_widget_control()">wp_register_widget_control()</a> after the argument list has been compiled.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.2.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>deprecated</th> <td>2.8.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>deprecated</th> <td>Use height.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_rel_canonical"></a><div class="element clickable function function_rel_canonical" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_rel_canonical .collapse"> <h2>Output rel=canonical for singular queries.</h2> <pre>rel_canonical() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.9.0</td> </tr> </table> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_remove_accents"></a><div class="element clickable function function_remove_accents" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_remove_accents .collapse"> <h2>Converts all accent characters to ASCII characters.</h2> <pre>remove_accents(string $string) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>If there are no accent characters, then the string given is just returned.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.2.1</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$string</h4> <code>string</code><p>Text that might have accent characters</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Filtered string with replaced "nice" characters.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_remove_action"></a><div class="element clickable function function_remove_action" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_remove_action .collapse"> <h2>Removes a function from a specified action hook.</h2> <pre>remove_action(string $tag, callback $function_to_remove, int $priority, int $accepted_args) : boolean</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This function removes a function attached to a specified action hook. This method can be used to remove default functions attached to a specific filter hook and possibly replace them with a substitute.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Plugin.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Plugin</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.2</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$tag</h4> <code>string</code><p>The action hook to which the function to be removed is hooked.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$function_to_remove</h4> <code>callback</code><p>The name of the function which should be removed.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$priority</h4> <code>int</code><p>optional The priority of the function (default: 10).</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$accepted_args</h4> <code>int</code><p>optional. The number of arguments the function accepts (default: 1).</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>boolean</code>Whether the function is removed.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_remove_all_actions"></a><div class="element clickable function function_remove_all_actions" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_remove_all_actions .collapse"> <h2>Remove all of the hooks from an action.</h2> <pre>remove_all_actions(string $tag, int $priority) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$tag</h4> <code>string</code><p>The action to remove hooks from.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$priority</h4> <code>int</code><p>The priority number to remove them from.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code>True when finished.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_remove_all_filters"></a><div class="element clickable function function_remove_all_filters" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_remove_all_filters .collapse"> <h2>Remove all of the hooks from a filter.</h2> <pre>remove_all_filters(string $tag, class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code>True on success, false if there were no stylesheets to remove.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_remove_filter"></a><div class="element clickable function function_remove_filter" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_remove_filter .collapse"> <h2>Removes a function from a specified filter hook.</h2> <pre>remove_filter(string $tag, callback $function_to_remove, int $priority, int $accepted_args) : boolean</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This function removes a function attached to a specified filter hook. This method can be used to remove default functions attached to a specific filter hook and possibly replace them with a substitute.</p> <p>To remove a hook, the $function_to_remove and $priority arguments must match when the hook was added. This goes for both filters and actions. No warning will be given on removal failure.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Plugin.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Plugin</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.2</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$tag</h4> <code>string</code><p>The filter hook to which the function to be removed is hooked.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$function_to_remove</h4> <code>callback</code><p>The name of the function which should be removed.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$priority</h4> <code>int</code><p>optional. The priority of the function (default: 10).</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$accepted_args</h4> <code>int</code><p>optional. The number of arguments the function accepts (default: 1).</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>boolean</code>Whether the function existed before it was removed.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_remove_menu_page"></a><div class="element clickable function function_remove_menu_page" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_remove_menu_page .collapse"> True on success.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_require_if_theme_supports"></a><div class="element clickable function function_require_if_theme_supports" data-toggle="collapse" table-bordered"> <tr> <th>link</th> <td><a href="http://archipelago.phrasewise.com/rsd">http://archipelago.phrasewise.com/rsd</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.0</td> </tr> </table> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_rss_enclosure"></a><div class="element clickable function function_rss_enclosure" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_rss_enclosure .collapse"> <h2>Display the rss enclosure for the current post.</h2> <pre>rss_enclosure() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Uses the global $post to check whether the post requires a password and if the user has the password for the post. If not then it will return before displaying.</p> <p>Also uses the function get_post_custom() to get the post's 'enclosure' metadata field and parses the value to display the enclosure(s). The enclosure(s) consist of enclosure HTML tag(s) with a URI and other attributes.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Template.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Template</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.5.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\get_post_custom()</td> </tr> </table> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_safecss_filter_attr"></a><div class="element clickable function function_safecss_filter_attr" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_safecss_filter_attr .collapse"> <h2>Inline CSS filter</h2> <pre>safecss_filter_attr($css, $deprecated) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.8.1</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"><h4>$css</h4></div> <div class="subelement argument"><h4>$deprecated</h4></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_bookmark"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_bookmark" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_bookmark .collapse"> <h2>Sanitizes all bookmark fields</h2> <pre>sanitize_bookmark(object | array $bookmark, string $context) : object | array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$bookmark</h4> <code>object</code><code>array</code><p>Bookmark row</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$context</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional, default is 'display'. How to filter the fields</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>object</code><code>array</code>Same type as $bookmark but with fields sanitized.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_bookmark_field"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_bookmark_field" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_bookmark_field .collapse"> <h2>Sanitizes a bookmark field</h2> <pre>sanitize_bookmark_field(string $field, mixed $value, int $bookmark_id, string $context) : mixed</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Sanitizes the bookmark fields based on what the field name is. If the field has a strict value set, then it will be tested for that, else a more generic filtering is applied. After the more strict filter is applied, if the $context is 'raw' then the value is immediately return.</p> <p>Hooks exist for the more generic cases. With the 'edit' context, the 'edit_$field' filter will be called and passed the $value and $bookmark_id respectively. With the 'db' context, the 'pre_$field' filter is called and passed the value. The 'display' context is the final context and has the $field has the filter name and is passed the $value, $bookmark_id, and $context respectively.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$field</h4> <code>string</code><p>The bookmark field</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$value</h4> <code>mixed</code><p>The bookmark field value</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$bookmark_id</h4> <code>int</code><p>Bookmark ID</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$context</h4> <code>string</code><p>How to filter the field value. Either 'raw', 'edit', 'attribute', 'js', 'db', or 'display'</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>mixed</code>The filtered value</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_category"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_category" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_category .collapse"> <h2>Sanitizes category data based on context.</h2> <pre>sanitize_category(object | array $category, string $context) : object | array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\sanitize_term()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$category</h4> <code>object</code><code>array</code><p>Category data</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$context</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. Default is 'display'.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>object</code><code>array</code>Same type as $category with sanitized data for safe use.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_category_field"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_category_field" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_category_field .collapse"> <h2>Sanitizes data in single category key field.</h2> <pre>sanitize_category_field(string $field, mixed $value, int $cat_id, string $context) : mixed</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\sanitize_term_field()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$field</h4> <code>string</code><p>Category key to sanitize</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$value</h4> <code>mixed</code><p>Category value to sanitize</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$cat_id</h4> <code>int</code><p>Category ID</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$context</h4> <code>string</code><p>What filter to use, 'raw', 'display', etc.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>mixed</code>Same type as $value after $value has been sanitized.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_comment_cookies"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_comment_cookies" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_comment_cookies .collapse"> <h2>Sanitizes the cookies sent to the user already.</h2> <pre>sanitize_comment_cookies() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Will only do anything if the cookies have already been created for the user. Mostly used after cookies had been sent to use elsewhere.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.4</td> </tr></table> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_email"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_email" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_email .collapse"> <h2>Strips out all characters that are not allowable in an email.</h2> <pre>sanitize_email(string $email) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.5.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$email</h4> <code>string</code><p>Email address to filter.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Filtered email address.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_file_name"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_file_name" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_file_name .collapse"> <h2>Sanitizes a filename replacing whitespace with dashes</h2> <pre>sanitize_file_name(string $filename) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Removes special characters that are illegal in filenames on certain operating systems and special characters requiring special escaping to manipulate at the command line. Replaces spaces and consecutive dashes with a single dash. Trim period, dash and underscore from beginning and end of filename.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.1.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$filename</h4> <code>string</code><p>The filename to be sanitized</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>The sanitized filename</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_hex_color"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_hex_color" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_hex_color .collapse"> <h2>Validates a hex color.</h2> <pre>sanitize_hex_color($color) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Returns either '', a 3 or 6 digit hex color (with #), or null. For validating values without a #, see sanitize_hex_color_no_hash().</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>3.4.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"><h4>$color</h4></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_hex_color_no_hash"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_hex_color_no_hash" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_hex_color_no_hash .collapse"> <h2>Sanitizes a hex color without a hash.</h2> <pre>sanitize_hex_color_no_hash($color) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Use sanitize_hex_color() when possible.</p> <p>Saving hex colors without a hash puts the burden of adding the hash on the UI, which makes it difficult to use or upgrade to other color types such as rgba, hsl, rgb, and html color names.</p> <p>Returns either '', a 3 or 6 digit hex color (without a #), or null.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>3.4.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"><h4>$color</h4></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_html_class"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_html_class" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_html_class .collapse"> <h2>Santizes a html classname to ensure it only contains valid characters</h2> <pre>sanitize_html_class(string $class, string $fallback) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Strips the string down to A-Z,a-z,0-9,_,-. If this results in an empty string then it will return the alternative value supplied.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>todo</th> <td>Expand to support the full range of CDATA that a class attribute can contain.</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.8.0</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$class</h4> <code>string</code><p>The classname to be sanitized</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$fallback</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. The value to return if the sanitization end's up as an empty string. Defaults to an empty string.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>The sanitized value</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_key"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_key" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_key .collapse"> <h2>Sanitize a string key.</h2> <pre>sanitize_key(string $key) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Keys are used as internal identifiers. field.</h2> <pre>sanitize_post(object | array $post, string $context) : object | array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>If the context is 'raw', then the post object or array will get minimal santization of the int fields.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> How to sanitize post fields.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>object</code><code>array</code>The now sanitized Post Object or Array (will be the same type as $post)</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_post_field"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_post_field" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_post_field .collapse"> <h2>Sanitize post field based on context.</h2> <pre>sanitize_post_field(string $field, mixed $value, int $post_id, string $context) : mixed</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Possible context values are: 'raw', 'edit', 'db', 'display', 'attribute' and 'js'. The 'display' context is used by default. 'attribute' and 'js' contexts are treated like 'display' when calling filters.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$field</h4> <code>string</code><p>The Post Object field name.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$value</h4> <code>mixed</code><p>The Post Object value.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$post_id</h4> <code>int</code><p>Post ID.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$context</h4> <code>string</code><p>How to sanitize post fields. Looks for 'raw', 'edit', 'db', 'display', 'attribute' and 'js'.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>mixed</code>Sanitized value.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_sql_orderby"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_sql_orderby" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_sql_orderby .collapse"> <h2>Ensures a string is a valid SQL order by clause.</h2> <pre>sanitize_sql_orderby(string $orderby) : string | false</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Accepts one or more columns, with or without ASC/DESC, and also accepts RAND().</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.5.1</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$orderby</h4> <code>string</code><p>Order by string to be checked.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code><code>false</code>Returns the order by clause if it is a match, false otherwise.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_term"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_term" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_term .collapse"> <h2>Sanitize Term all fields.</h2> <pre>sanitize_term(array | object $term, string $taxonomy, string $context) : array | object</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Relies on sanitize_term_field() to sanitize the term. The difference is that this function will sanitize <strong>all</strong> fields. The context is based on sanitize_term_field().</p> <p>The $term is expected to be either an array or an object.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Taxonomy.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Taxonomy</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\sanitize_term_field</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$term</h4> <code>array</code><code>object</code><p>The term to check</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$taxonomy</h4> <code>string</code><p>The taxonomy name to use</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$context</h4> <code>string</code><p>Default is 'display'.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>array</code><code>object</code>Term with all fields sanitized</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_term_field"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_term_field" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_term_field .collapse"> <h2>Cleanse the field value in the term based on the context.</h2> <pre>sanitize_term_field(string $field, string $value, int $term_id, string $taxonomy, string $context) : mixed</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Passing a term field value through the function should be assumed to have cleansed the value for whatever context the term field is going to be used.</p> <p>If no context or an unsupported context is given, then default filters will be applied.</p> <p>There are enough filters for each context to support a custom filtering without creating your own filter function. Simply create a function that hooks into the filter you need.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Taxonomy.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Taxonomy</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$wpdb</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$field</h4> <code>string</code><p>Term field to sanitize</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$value</h4> <code>string</code><p>Search for this term value</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$term_id</h4> <code>int</code><p>Term ID</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$taxonomy</h4> <code>string</code><p>Taxonomy Name</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$context</h4> <code>string</code><p>Either edit, db, display, attribute, or js.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>mixed</code>sanitized field</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_text_field"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_text_field" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_text_field .collapse"> <h2>Sanitize a string from user input or from the db</h2> <pre>sanitize_text_field(string $str) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>check for invalid UTF-8, Convert single < characters to entity, strip all tags, remove line breaks, tabs and extra white space, strip octets.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.9.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$str</h4> <code>string</code> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"><code>string</code></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_title"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_title" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_title .collapse"> <h2>Sanitizes title or use fallback title.</h2> <pre>sanitize_title(string $title, string $fallback_title, string $context) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Specifically, HTML and PHP tags are stripped. Further actions can be added via the plugin API. If $title is empty and $fallback_title is set, the latter will be used.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$title</h4> <code>string</code><p>The string to be sanitized.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$fallback_title</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. A title to use if $title is empty.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$context</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. The operation for which the string is sanitized</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>The sanitized string.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_title_for_query"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_title_for_query" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_title_for_query .collapse"> <h2>sanitize_title_for_query() </h2> <pre>sanitize_title_for_query($title) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"><h4>$title</h4></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_title_with_dashes"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_title_with_dashes" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_title_with_dashes .collapse"> <h2>Sanitizes title, replacing whitespace and a few other characters with dashes.</h2> <pre>sanitize_title_with_dashes(string $title, string $raw_title, string $context) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Limits the output to alphanumeric characters, underscore (_) and dash (-). Whitespace becomes a dash.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.2.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$title</h4> <code>string</code><p>The title to be sanitized.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$raw_title</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. Not used.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$context</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. The operation for which the string is sanitized.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>The sanitized title.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_trackback_urls"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_trackback_urls" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_trackback_urls .collapse"> starting with the http or https protocol, separated by a carriage return.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_url"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_url" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_url .collapse"> <h2>Performs esc_url() for database or redirect usage.</h2> <pre>sanitize_url(string $url, array $protocols) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.1</td> </tr> <tr> function function_sanitize_user" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_user .collapse"> <h2>Sanitize username stripping out unsafe characters.</h2> <pre>sanitize_user(string $username, bool $strict) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Removes tags, octets, entities, and if strict is enabled, will only keep alphanumeric, _, space, ., -, @. After sanitizing, it passes the username, raw username (the username in the parameter), and the value of $strict as parameters for the 'sanitize_user' filter.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$username</h4> <code>string</code><p>The username to be sanitized.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$strict</h4> <code>bool</code><p>If set limits $username to specific characters. Default false.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>The sanitized username, after passing through filters.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_user_field"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_user_field" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_user_field .collapse"> <h2>Sanitize user field based on context.</h2> <pre>sanitize_user_field(string $field, mixed $value, int $user_id, string $context) : mixed</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Possible context values are: 'raw', 'edit', 'db', 'display', 'attribute' and 'js'. The 'display' context is used by default. 'attribute' and 'js' contexts are treated like 'display' when calling filters.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$field</h4> <code>string</code><p>The user Object field name.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$value</h4> <code>mixed</code><p>The user Object value.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$user_id</h4> <code>int</code><p>user ID.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$context</h4> <code>string</code><p>How to sanitize user fields. Looks for 'raw', 'edit', 'db', 'display', 'attribute' and 'js'.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>mixed</code>Sanitized value.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sanitize_user_object"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sanitize_user_object" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_sanitize_user_object .collapse"> <h2>Sanitize every user field.</h2> <pre>sanitize_user_object(object | array $user, string $context) : object | array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>If the context is 'raw', then the user object or array will get minimal santization of the int fields.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>deprecated</th> <td>3.3.0</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$user</h4> <code>object</code><code>array</code><p>The User Object or Array</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$context</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional, default is 'display'. How to sanitize user fields.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>object</code><code>array</code>The now sanitized User Object or Array (will be the same type as $user)</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_saveDomDocument"></a><div class="element clickable function function_saveDomDocument" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_saveDomDocument Outputs a</p> <p><</p> <p>div> for each error retrieved by get_settings_errors().</p> <p>This is called automatically after a settings page based on the Settings API is submitted. Errors should be added during the validation callback function for a setting defined in register_setting()</p> <p>The $sanitize option is passed into get_settings_errors() and will re-run the setting sanitization on its current value.</p> <p>The $hide_on_update option will cause errors to only show when the settings page is first loaded. if the user has already saved new values it will be hidden to avoid repeating messages already shown in the default error reporting after submission. This is useful to show general errors like missing settings when the user arrives at the settings page.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>3.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$setting</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional slug title of a specific setting who's errors you want.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$sanitize</h4> <code>boolean</code><p>Whether to re-sanitize the setting value before returning errors.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$hide_on_update</h4> <code>boolean</code><p>If set to true errors will not be shown if the settings page has already been submitted.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_settings_fields"></a><div class="element clickable function function_settings_fields" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_settings_fields .collapse"> <h2>Output nonce, action, and option_page fields for a settings page.</h2> <pre>settings_fields(string $option_group) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$option_group</h4> <code>string</code><p>A settings group name. The returned attributes will only contain the attributes in the $pairs list.</p> <p>If the $atts list has unsupported attributes, then they will be ignored and removed from the final returned list.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.5</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$pairs</h4> <code>array</code><p>Entire list of supported attributes and their defaults.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$atts</h4> <code>array</code><p>User defined attributes in shortcode tag.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>array</code>Combined and filtered attribute list.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_shortcode_parse_atts"></a><div class="element clickable function function_shortcode_parse_atts" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_shortcode_parse_atts .collapse"> <h2>Retrieve all attributes from the shortcodes tag.</h2> <pre>shortcode_parse_atts(string $text) : array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The attributes list has the attribute name as the key and the value of the attribute as the value in the key/value pair. This allows for easier retrieval of the attributes, since all attributes have to be known.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.5</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$text</h4> <code>string</code> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>array</code>List of attributes and their value.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_shortcode_unautop"></a><div class="element clickable function function_shortcode_unautop" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_shortcode_unautop .collapse"> <h2>Don't auto-p wrap shortcodes that stand alone</h2> <pre>shortcode_unautop(string $pee) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Ensures that shortcodes are not wrapped in <</p> <p>>...<</p> <blockquote> <p>.</p> </blockquote></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.9.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$pee</h4> <code>string</code><p>The content.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>The filtered content.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_show_admin_bar"></a><div class="element clickable function function_show_admin_bar" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_show_admin_bar .collapse"> <h2>Set the display status of the admin bar.</h2> <pre>show_admin_bar(bool $show) : void</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This can be called immediately upon plugin load. argument"><h4>$errors</h4></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_single_cat_title"></a><div class="element clickable function function_single_cat_title" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_single_cat_title .collapse"> <h2>Display or retrieve page title for category archive.</h2> <pre>single_cat_title(string $prefix, bool $display) : string | null</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This is useful for category template file or files, because it is optimized for category page title and with less overhead than <a href="wp_title()">wp_title()</a>.</p> <p>It does not support placing the separator after the title, but by leaving the prefix parameter empty, you can set the title separator manually. The prefix does not automatically place a space between the prefix, so if there should be a space, the parameter value will need to have it at the end.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>0.71</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$prefix</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. What to display before the title.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$display</h4> <code>bool</code><p>Optional, default is true. Whether to display or retrieve title.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code><code>null</code>Title when retrieving, null when displaying or failure.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_single_month_title"></a><div class="element clickable function function_single_month_title" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_single_month_title .collapse"> <h2>Display or retrieve page title for post archive based on date.</h2> <pre>single_month_title(string $prefix, bool $display) : string | null</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Useful for when the template only needs to display the month and year, if either are available. The prefix does not automatically place a space between the prefix, so if there should be a space, the parameter value will need to have it at the end.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>0.71</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$prefix</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. If $scheme is 'http' or 'https', is_ssl() is overridden.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.6.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\get_site_url()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$path</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. Path relative to the site url.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$scheme</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. Scheme to give the site url context. Currently 'http', 'https', 'login', 'login_post', 'admin', or 'relative'.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Site url link with optional path appended.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_size_format"></a><div class="element clickable function function_size_format" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_size_format .collapse"> <h2>Convert number of bytes largest unit bytes will fit into.</h2> <pre>size_format(int | string $bytes, int $decimals) : bool | string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>It is easier to read 1kB than 1024 bytes and 1MB than 1048576 bytes. Converts number of bytes to human readable number by taking the number of that unit that the bytes will go into it. Supports TB value.</p> <p>Please note that integers in PHP are limited to 32 bits, unless they are on 64 bit architecture, then they have 64 bit size. If you need to place the larger size then what PHP integer type will hold, then use a string. It will be converted to a double, which should always have 64 bit length.</p> <p>Technically the correct unit names for powers of 1024 are KiB, MiB etc.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>link</th> <td><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byte">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byte</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$bytes</h4> <code>int</code><code>string</code><p>Number of bytes. Note max integer size for integers.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$decimals</h4> <code>int</code><p>Precision of number of decimal places. Deprecated.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code><code>string</code>False on failure. Number string on success.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_smilies_init"></a><div class="element clickable function function_smilies_init" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_smilies_init .collapse"> <h2>Convert smiley code to the icon graphic file equivalent.</h2> <pre>smilies_init() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>You can turn off smilies, by going to the write setting screen and unchecking the box, or by setting 'use_smilies' option to false or removing the option.</p> <p>Plugins may override the default smiley list by setting the $wpsmiliestrans to an array, with the key the code the blogger types in and the value the image file.</p> <p>The $wp_smiliessearch global is for the regular expression and is set each time the function is called.</p> <p>The full list of smilies can be found in the function and won't be listed in the description. Probably should create a Codex page for it, so that it is available.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>global</th> <td>array $wpsmiliestrans</td> </tr> <tr> <th>global</th> <td>array $wp_smiliessearch</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.2.0</td> </tr> </table> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_sort_menu"></a><div class="element clickable function function_sort_menu" class="element clickable function function_stripslashes_deep" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_stripslashes_deep .collapse"> <h2>Navigates through an array and removes slashes from the values.</h2> <pre>stripslashes_deep(array | string $value) : array | string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>If an array is passed, the array_map() function causes a callback to pass the value back to the function. The slashes from this value will removed.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$value</h4> <code>array</code><code>string</code><p>The array or string to be stripped.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>array</code><code>string</code>Stripped array (or string in the callback).</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_submit_button"></a><div class="element clickable function function_submit_button" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_submit_button .collapse"> <h2>Echos a submit button, with provided text and appropriate class</h2> <pre>submit_button(string $text, string $type, string $name, bool $wrap, array | string $other_attributes) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>3.1.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$text</h4> <code>string</code><p>The text of the button (defaults to 'Save Changes')</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$type</h4> <code>string</code><p>The type of button. One of: primary, secondary, delete</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$name</h4> <code>string</code><p>The HTML name of the submit button. Defaults to "submit". If no id attribute is given in $other_attributes below, $name will be used as the button's id.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$wrap</h4> <code>bool</code><p>True if the output button should be wrapped in a paragraph tag, false otherwise. Defaults to true</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$other_attributes</h4> <code>array</code><code>string</code><p>Other attributes that should be output with the button, mapping attributes to their values, such as array( 'tabindex' => '1' ). These attributes will be output as attribute="value", such as tabindex="1". Defaults to no other attributes. Other attributes can also be provided as a string such as 'tabindex="1"', though the array format is typically cleaner.</p> </div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_switch_theme"></a><div class="element clickable function function_switch_theme" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_switch_theme .collapse"> <h2>Switches current theme to new template and stylesheet names.</h2> <pre>switch_theme(string $template, string $stylesheet) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.5.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$template</h4> <code>string</code><p>Template name</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$stylesheet</h4> <code>string</code><p>Stylesheet name.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_switch_to_blog"></a><div class="element clickable function function_switch_to_blog" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_switch_to_blog .collapse"> <h2>Switch the current blog.</h2> <pre>switch_to_blog(int $new_blog, bool $validate) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This function is useful if you need to pull posts, or other information, from other blogs. You can switch back afterwards using restore_current_blog().</p> <p>Things that aren't switched: - autoloaded options. See #14992 - plugins. See #14941</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\restore_current_blog()</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>MU</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$new_blog</h4> <code>int</code><p>The id of the blog you want to switch to. This function is not deprecated, but is designed to echo the value from get_the_author() and as an result of any old theme that might still use the old behavior will also pass the value from get_the_author().</p> <p>The normal, expected behavior of this function is to echo the author and not return it. However, backwards compatibility has to be maintained.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>0.71</td> </tr> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\get_the_author()</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>link</th> <td><a href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags/the_author">http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags/the_author</a></td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$deprecated</h4> <code>string</code><p>Deprecated.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$deprecated_echo</h4> <code>string</code><p>Deprecated. Use get_the_author(). Echo the string or return it.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>The author's display name, from get_the_author().</div> </div></div> </div> <a data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_the_author_posts_link .collapse"> <h2>Display an HTML link to the author page of the author of the current post.</h2> <pre>the_author_posts_link(string $deprecated) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Does just echo get_author_posts_url() function, like the others do. The reason for this, is that another function is used to help in printing the link to the author's posts.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>link</th> <td><a href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags/the_author_posts_link">http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags/the_author_posts_link</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.2.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$authordata</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\get_author_posts_url()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\get_the_author()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$deprecated</h4> <code>string</code><p>Deprecated.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_the_author_url"></a><div class="element clickable function function_the_author_url" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_the_author_url .collapse"> <h2>Display the URL to the home page of the author of the current post.</h2> <pre>the_author_url() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>0.71</td> </tr> <tr> <th>deprecated</th> <td>2.8</td> </tr> <tr> <th>deprecated</th> <td>Use the_author_meta('url')</td> </tr> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\the_author_meta()</a></td> </tr> </table> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_the_author_yim"></a><div class="element clickable function function_the_author_yim" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_the_author_yim .collapse"> <h2>Display the Yahoo! IM name of the author of the current post.</h2> <pre>the_author_yim() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>0.71</td> </tr> <tr> <th>deprecated</th> <td>2.8</td> </tr> <tr> <th>deprecated</th> <td>Use the_author_meta('yim')</td> </tr> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\the_author_meta()</a></td> </tr> </table> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_the_category"></a><div class="element clickable function function_the_category" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_the_category .collapse"> <h2>Display the category list for the post.</h2> <pre>the_category(string $separator, string $parents, int $post_id) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>0.71</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$separator</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional, default is empty string. class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a
