class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\wp_debug_mode()</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>3.0.0</td> </tr> </table> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_initial_nav_menu_meta_boxes"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_initial_nav_menu_meta_boxes" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_initial_nav_menu_meta_boxes .collapse"> <h2>Limit the amount of meta boxes to just links, pages and cats for first time users.</h2> <pre>wp_initial_nav_menu_meta_boxes() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>3.0.0</td> </tr></table> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_insert_attachment"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_insert_attachment" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_insert_attachment .collapse"> <h2>Insert an attachment.</h2> <pre>wp_insert_attachment(string | array $object, string $file, int $parent) : int</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>If you set the 'ID' in the $object parameter, it will mean that you are updating and attempt to update the attachment. You can also set the attachment name or title by setting the key 'post_name' or 'post_title'.</p> <p>You can set the dates for the attachment manually by setting the 'post_date' and 'post_date_gmt' keys' values.</p> <p>By default, the comments will use the default settings for whether the comments are allowed. You can close them manually or keep them open by setting the value for the 'comment_status' key.</p> <p>The $object parameter can have the following: 'post_status' - Default is 'draft'. Can not be overridden, set the same as parent post. 'post_type' - Default is 'post', will be set to attachment. Can not override. 'post_author' - Default is current user ID. The ID of the user, who added the attachment. 'ping_status' - Default is the value in default ping status option. Whether the attachment can accept pings. 'post_parent' - Default is 0. Can use $parent parameter or set this for the post it belongs to, if any. 'menu_order' - Default is 0. The order it is displayed. 'to_ping' - Whether to ping. 'pinged' - Default is empty string. 'post_password' - Default is empty string. The password to access the attachment. 'guid' - Global Unique ID for referencing the attachment. 'post_content_filtered' - Attachment post content filtered. 'post_excerpt' - Attachment excerpt.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$wpdb</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$user_ID</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$object</h4> <code>string</code><code>array</code><p>Arguments to override defaults.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$file</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional filename.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$parent</h4> <code>int</code><p>Parent post ID.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>int</code>Attachment ID.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_insert_category"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_insert_category" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_insert_category .collapse"> <h2>Updates an existing Category or creates a new Category.</h2> <pre>wp_insert_category(mixed $catarr, bool $wp_error) : int | object</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$catarr</h4> <code>mixed</code><p>See defaults below. Set 'cat_ID' to a non-zero value to update an existing category. The 'taxonomy' key was added in 3.0.0.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$wp_error</h4> <code>bool</code><p>Optional, since 2.5.0. Set this to true if the caller handles WP_Error return values.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>int</code><code>object</code>The ID number of the new or updated Category on success. Zero or a WP_Error on failure, depending on param $wp_error.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_insert_comment"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_insert_comment" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_insert_comment .collapse"> <h2>Inserts a comment to the database.</h2> <pre>wp_insert_comment(array $commentdata) : int</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The available comment data key names are 'comment_author_IP', 'comment_date', 'comment_date_gmt', 'comment_parent', 'comment_approved', and 'user_id'.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$wpdb</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$commentdata</h4> <code>array</code><p>Contains information on the comment.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>int</code>The new comment's ID.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_insert_link"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_insert_link" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_insert_link .collapse"> <h2>This function inserts/updates links into/in the database.</h2> <pre>wp_insert_link(array $linkdata, bool $wp_error) : int | <a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$linkdata</h4> <code>array</code><p>Elements that make up the link to insert.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$wp_error</h4> <code>bool</code><p>Optional. If true return WP_Error object on failure.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>int</code><code><a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></code>Value 0 or WP_Error on failure. The link ID on success.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_insert_post"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_insert_post" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_insert_post .collapse"> <h2>Insert a post.</h2> <pre>wp_insert_post(array $postarr, bool $wp_error) : int | <a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>If the $postarr parameter has 'ID' set to a value, then post will be updated.</p> <p>You can set the post date manually, but setting the values for 'post_date' and 'post_date_gmt' keys. You can close the comments or open the comments by setting the value for 'comment_status' key.</p> <p>The defaults for the parameter $postarr are: 'post_status' - Default is 'draft'. 'post_type' - Default is 'post'. 'post_author' - Default is current user ID ($user_ID). The ID of the user who added the post. 'ping_status' - Default is the value in 'default_ping_status' option. Whether the attachment can accept pings. 'post_parent' - Default is 0. Set this for the post it belongs to, if any. 'menu_order' - Default is 0. The order it is displayed. 'to_ping' - Whether to ping. 'pinged' - Default is empty string. 'post_password' - Default is empty string. The password to access the attachment. 'guid' - Global Unique ID for referencing the attachment. 'post_content_filtered' - Post content filtered. 'post_excerpt' - Post excerpt.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$wpdb</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$user_ID</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\wp_transition_post_status()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$postarr</h4> <code>array</code><p>Elements that make up post to insert.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$wp_error</h4> <code>bool</code><p>Optional. Allow return of WP_Error on failure.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>int</code><code><a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></code>The value 0 or WP_Error on failure. The post ID on success.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_insert_term"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_insert_term" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_insert_term .collapse"> <h2>Adds a new term to the database.</h2> <pre>wp_insert_term(string $term, string $taxonomy, array | string $args) : array | <a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Optionally marks it as an alias of an existing term.</p> <p>Error handling is assigned for the nonexistence of the $taxonomy and $term parameters before inserting. If both the term id and taxonomy exist previously, then an array will be returned that contains the term id and the contents of what is returned. The keys of the array are 'term_id' and 'term_taxonomy_id' containing numeric values.</p> <p>It is assumed that the term does not yet exist or the above will apply. The term will be first added to the term table and then related to the taxonomy if everything is well. If everything is correct, then several actions will be run prior to a filter and then several actions will be run after the filter is run.</p> <p>The arguments decide how the term is handled based on the $args parameter. The following is a list of the available overrides and the defaults.</p> <p>'alias_of'. There is no default, but if added, expected is the slug that the term will be an alias of. Expected to be a string.</p> <p>'description'. There is no default. If exists, will be added to the database along with the term. Expected to be a string.</p> <p>'parent'. Expected to be numeric and default is 0 (zero). Will assign value of 'parent' to the term.</p> <p>'slug'. Expected to be a string. There is no default.</p> <p>If 'slug' argument exists then the slug will be checked to see if it is not a valid term. If that check succeeds (it is not a valid term), then it is added and the term id is given. If it fails, then a check is made to whether the taxonomy is hierarchical and the parent argument is not empty. If the second check succeeds, the term will be inserted and the term id will be given.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Taxonomy.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Taxonomy</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$wpdb</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$term</h4> <code>string</code><p>The term to add or update.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$taxonomy</h4> <code>string</code><p>The taxonomy to which to add the term</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><code>string</code><p>Change the values of the inserted term</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>array</code><code><a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></code>The Term ID and Term Taxonomy ID</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_insert_user"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_insert_user" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_insert_user .collapse"> <h2>Insert an user into the database.</h2> <pre>wp_insert_user(array $userdata) : int | <a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Can update a current user or insert a new user based on whether the user's ID is present.</p> <p>Can be used to update the user's info (see below), set the user's role, and set the user's preference on whether they want the rich editor on.</p> <p>Most of the $userdata array fields have filters associated with the values. The exceptions are 'rich_editing', 'role', 'jabber', 'aim', 'yim', 'user_registered', and 'ID'. The filters have the prefix 'pre_user_' followed by the field name. An example using 'description' would have the filter called, 'pre_user_description' that can be hooked into.</p> <p>The $userdata array can contain the following fields: 'ID' - An integer that will be used for updating an existing user. 'user_pass' - A string that contains the plain text password for the user. 'user_login' - A string that contains the user's username for logging in. 'user_nicename' - A string that contains a nicer looking name for the user. The default is the user's username. 'user_url' - A string containing the user's URL for the user's web site. 'user_email' - A string containing the user's email address. 'display_name' - A string that will be shown on the site. Defaults to user's username. It is likely that you will want to change this, for appearance. 'nickname' - The user's nickname, defaults to the user's username. 'first_name' - The user's first name. 'last_name' - The user's last name. 'description' - A string containing content about the user. 'rich_editing' - A string for whether to enable the rich editor. False if not empty. 'user_registered' - The date the user registered. Format is 'Y-m-d H:i:s'. 'role' - A string used to set the user's role. 'jabber' - User's Jabber account. 'aim' - User's AOL IM account. 'yim' - User's Yahoo IM account.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$wpdb</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$userdata</h4> <code>array</code><p>An array of user data.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>int</code><code><a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></code>The newly created user's ID or a WP_Error object if the user could not be created.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_install"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_install" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_install .collapse"> <h2>Installs the blog</h2> <pre>wp_install(string $blog_title, string $user_name, string $user_email, bool $public, null $deprecated, string $user_password) : array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p></p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.1.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$blog_title</h4> <code>string</code><p>Blog title.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$user_name</h4> <code>string</code><p>User's username.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$user_email</h4> <code>string</code><p>User's email.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$public</h4> <code>bool</code><p>Whether blog is public.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$deprecated</h4> <code>null</code><p>Optional. Not used.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$user_password</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. User's chosen password. Will default to a random password.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>array</code>Array keys 'url', 'user_id', 'password', 'password_message'.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_install_defaults"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_install_defaults" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_install_defaults .collapse"> <h2>{@internal Missing Short Description}}</h2> <pre>wp_install_defaults(int $user_id) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p></p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.1.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$user_id</h4> <code>int</code><p>User ID.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_is_large_network"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_is_large_network" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_is_large_network .collapse"> <h2>Whether or not we have a large network.</h2> <pre>wp_is_large_network(string $using) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The default criteria for a large network is either more than 10,000 users or more than 10,000 sites. Plugins can alter this criteria using the 'wp_is_large_network' filter.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>3.3.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$using</h4> <code>string</code><p>'sites or 'users'. if the specified post is a revision.</h2> <pre>wp_is_post_revision(int | object $post) : bool | int</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div string to ASCII</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_just_in_time_script_localization"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_just_in_time_script_localization" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_just_in_time_script_localization .collapse"> <h2>Load localized data on print rather than initialization.</h2> <pre>wp_just_in_time_script_localization() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>These localizations require information that may not be loaded even by init.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.5.0</td> </tr></table> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_kses"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_kses" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_kses .collapse"> <h2>Filters content and keeps only allowable HTML elements.</h2> <pre>wp_kses(string $string, array $allowed_html, array $allowed_protocols) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This function makes sure that only the allowed HTML element names, attribute names and attribute values plus only sane HTML entities will occur in $string. You have to remove any slashes from PHP's magic quotes before you call this function.</p> <p>The default allowed protocols are 'http', 'https', 'ftp', 'mailto', 'news', 'irc', 'gopher', 'nntp', 'feed', 'telnet, 'mms', 'rtsp' and 'svn'. This covers all common link protocols, except for 'javascript' which should not be allowed for untrusted users.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$string</h4> <code>string</code><p>Content to filter through kses</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$allowed_html</h4> <code>array</code><p>List of allowed HTML elements</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$allowed_protocols</h4> <code>array</code><p>Optional. Allowed protocol in links.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Filtered content with only allowed HTML elements</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_kses_array_lc"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_kses_array_lc" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_kses_array_lc .collapse"> <h2>Goes through an array and changes the keys to all lower case.</h2> <pre>wp_kses_array_lc(array $inarray) : array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$inarray</h4> <code>array</code><p>Unfiltered array</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>array</code>Fixed array with all lowercase keys</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_kses_attr"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_kses_attr" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_kses_attr .collapse"> <h2>Removes all attributes, if none are allowed for this element.</h2> <pre>wp_kses_attr(string $element, string $attr, array $allowed_html, array $allowed_protocols) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>If some are allowed it calls wp_kses_hair() to split them further, and then it builds up new HTML code from the data that kses_hair() returns. It also removes "<" and ">" characters, if there are any left. One more thing it does is to check if the tag has a closing XHTML slash, and if it does, it puts one in the returned code as well.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$element</h4> <code>string</code><p>HTML element/tag</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$attr</h4> <code>string</code><p>HTML attributes from HTML element to closing HTML element tag</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$allowed_html</h4> <code>array</code><p>Allowed HTML elements</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$allowed_protocols</h4> <code>array</code><p>Allowed protocols to keep</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Sanitized HTML element</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_kses_bad_protocol"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_kses_bad_protocol" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_kses_bad_protocol .collapse"> <h2>Sanitize string from bad protocols.</h2> <pre>wp_kses_bad_protocol(string $string, array $allowed_protocols) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This function removes all non-allowed protocols from the beginning of $string. It ignores whitespace and the case of the letters, and it does understand HTML entities. It does its work in a while loop, so it won't be fooled by a string like "javascript:javascript:alert(57)".</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$string</h4> <code>string</code><p>Content to filter bad protocols from</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$allowed_protocols</h4> <code>array</code><p>Allowed protocols to keep</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Filtered content</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_kses_bad_protocol_once"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_kses_bad_protocol_once" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_kses_bad_protocol_once .collapse"> <h2>Sanitizes content from bad protocols and other characters.</h2> <pre>wp_kses_bad_protocol_once(string $string, string $allowed_protocols, $count) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This function searches for URL protocols at the beginning of $string, while handling whitespace and HTML entities.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$string</h4> <code>string</code><p>Content to check for bad protocols</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$allowed_protocols</h4> <code>string</code><p>Allowed protocols</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"><h4>$count</h4></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Sanitized content</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_kses_bad_protocol_once2"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_kses_bad_protocol_once2" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_kses_bad_protocol_once2 .collapse"> <h2>Callback for wp_kses_bad_protocol_once() regular expression.</h2> <pre>wp_kses_bad_protocol_once2(string $string, string $allowed_protocols) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This function processes URL protocols, checks to see if they're in the whitelist or not, and returns different data depending on the answer.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>access</th> <td>private</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$string</h4> <code>string</code><p>URI scheme to check against the whitelist</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$allowed_protocols</h4> <code>string</code><p>Allowed protocols</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Sanitized content</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_kses_check_attr_val"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_kses_check_attr_val" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_kses_check_attr_val .collapse"> <h2>Performs different checks for attribute values.</h2> <pre>wp_kses_check_attr_val(string $value, string $vless, string $checkname, mixed $checkvalue) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The currently implemented checks are "maxlen", "minlen", "maxval", "minval" and "valueless".</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$value</h4> <code>string</code><p>Attribute value</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$vless</h4> <code>string</code><p>Whether the value is valueless. Use 'y' or 'n'</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$checkname</h4> <code>string</code><p>What $checkvalue is checking for.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$checkvalue</h4> <code>mixed</code><p>What constraint the value should pass</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code>Whether check passes</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_kses_data"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_kses_data" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_kses_data .collapse"> <h2>Sanitize content with allowed HTML Kses rules.</h2> <pre>wp_kses_data(string $data) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.9.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$allowedtags</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$data</h4> <code>string</code><p>Content to filter, expected to not be escaped</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Filtered content</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_kses_decode_entities"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_kses_decode_entities" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_kses_decode_entities .collapse"> <h2>Convert all entities to their character counterparts.</h2> <pre>wp_kses_decode_entities(string $string) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This function decodes numeric HTML entities (A and A). It doesn't do anything with other entities like ä, but we don't need them in the URL protocol whitelisting system anyway.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$string</h4> <code>string</code><p>Content to change entities</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Content after decoded entities</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_kses_hair"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_kses_hair" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_kses_hair .collapse"> <h2>Builds an attribute list from string containing attributes.</h2> <pre>wp_kses_hair(string $attr, array $allowed_protocols) : array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This function does a lot of work. It parses an attribute list into an array with attribute data, and tries to do the right thing even if it gets weird input. It will add quotes around attribute values that don't have any quotes or apostrophes around them, to make it easier to produce HTML code that will conform to W3C's HTML specification. It will also remove bad URL protocols from attribute values. It also reduces duplicate attributes by using the attribute defined first (foo='bar' foo='baz' will result in foo='bar').</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$attr</h4> <code>string</code><p>Attribute list from HTML element to closing HTML element tag</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$allowed_protocols</h4> <code>array</code><p>Allowed protocols to keep</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>array</code>List of attributes after parsing</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_kses_hook"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_kses_hook" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_kses_hook .collapse"> <h2>You add any kses hooks here.</h2> <pre>wp_kses_hook(string $string, array $allowed_html, array $allowed_protocols) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>There is currently only one kses WordPress hook and it is called here. All parameters are passed to the hooks and expected to receive a string.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$string</h4> <code>string</code><p>Content to filter through kses</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$allowed_html</h4> <code>array</code><p>List of allowed HTML elements</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$allowed_protocols</h4> <code>array</code><p>Allowed protocol in links</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Filtered content through 'pre_kses' hook</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_kses_html_error"></a><div class="element clickable function <h2>Callback for wp_kses_split for fixing malformed HTML tags.</h2> <pre>wp_kses_split2(string $string, array $allowed_html, array $allowed_protocols) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This function does a lot of work. It rejects some very malformed things like <:::>. It returns an empty string, if the element isn't allowed (look ma, no strip_tags()!). Otherwise it splits the tag into an element and an attribute list.</p> <p>After the tag is split into an element and an attribute list, it is run through another filter which will remove illegal attributes and once that is completed, will be returned.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>access</th> <td>private</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\wp_kses_attr()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$string</h4> <code>string</code><p>Content to filter</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$allowed_html</h4> <code>array</code><p>Allowed HTML elements</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$allowed_protocols</h4> <code>array</code><p>Allowed protocols to keep</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Fixed HTML element</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_kses_stripslashes"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_kses_stripslashes" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_kses_stripslashes .collapse"> <h2>Strips slashes from in front of quotes.</h2> <pre>wp_kses_stripslashes(string $string) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This function changes the character sequence \" to just ". It leaves all other slashes alone. It's really weird, but the quoting from preg_replace(//e) seems to require this.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$string</h4> <code>string</code><p>String to strip slashes</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Fixed string with quoted slashes</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_kses_version"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_kses_version" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_kses_version data-target=".function_wp_link_category_checklist .collapse"> <h2>{@internal Missing Short Description}}</h2> <pre>wp_link_category_checklist(\unknown_type $link_id) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.5.1</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$link_id</h4> <code>\unknown_type</code> </div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_link_pages"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_link_pages" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_link_pages .collapse"> <h2>The formatted output of a list of pages.</h2> <pre>wp_link_pages(string | array $args) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Displays page links for paginated posts (i.e. includes the <!--nextpage-->. Quicktag one or more times). This tag must be within The Loop.</p> <p>The defaults for overwriting are: 'next_or_number' - Default is 'number' (string). Indicates whether page numbers should be used. Valid values are number and next. 'nextpagelink' - Default is 'Next Page' (string). Text for link to next page. of the bookmark. 'previouspagelink' - Default is 'Previous Page' (string). Text for link to previous page, if available. 'pagelink' - Default is '%' (String).Format string for page numbers. The % in the parameter string will be replaced with the page number, so Page % generates "Page 1", "Page 2", etc. Defaults to %, just the page number. 'before' - Default is '</p> <p> Pages:' (string). The html or text to prepend to each bookmarks. 'after' - Default is '</p> <p>' (string). The html or text to append to each bookmarks. 'link_before' - Default is '' (string). The html or text to prepend to each Pages link inside the <a> tag. Also prepended to the current item, which is not linked. 'link_after' - Default is '' (string). The html or text to append to each Pages link inside the <a> tag. Also appended to the current item, which is not linked.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.2.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>access</th> <td>private</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>string</code><code>array</code><p>Optional. Overwrite the defaults.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Formatted output in HTML.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_list_authors"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_list_authors" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_list_authors .collapse"> <h2>List all the authors of the blog, with several options available.</h2> <pre>wp_list_authors(array $args) : null | string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><ul> <li>optioncount (boolean) (false): Show the count in parenthesis next to the author's name.</li> <li>exclude_admin (boolean) (true): Exclude the 'admin' user that is installed bydefault.</li> <li>show_fullname (boolean) (false): Show their full names.</li> <li>hide_empty (boolean) (true): Don't show authors without any posts.</li> <li>feed (string) (''): If isn't empty, show links to author's feeds.</li> <li>feed_image (string) (''): If isn't empty, use this image to link to feeds.</li> <li>echo (boolean) (true): Set to false to return the output, instead of echoing.</li> <li>style (string) ('list'): Whether to display list of authors in list form or as a string.</li> <li>html (bool) (true): Whether to list the items in html form or plaintext. </li> </ul></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>link</th> <td><a href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags/wp_list_authors">http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags/wp_list_authors</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.2.0</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><p>The argument array.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>null</code><code>string</code>The output, if echo is set to false.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_list_bookmarks"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_list_bookmarks" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_list_bookmarks .collapse"> <h2>Retrieve or echo all of the bookmarks.</h2> <pre>wp_list_bookmarks(string | array $args) : string | null</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>List of default arguments are as follows: 'orderby' - Default is 'name' (string). How to order the links by. String is based off of the bookmark scheme. 'order' - Default is 'ASC' (string). Either 'ASC' or 'DESC'. Orders in either ascending or descending order. 'limit' - Default is -1 (integer) or show all. The amount of bookmarks to display. 'category' - Default is empty string (string). Include the links in what category ID(s). 'category_name' - Default is empty string (string). Get links by category name. 'hide_invisible' - Default is 1 (integer). Whether to show (default) or hide links marked as 'invisible'. 'show_updated' - Default is 0 (integer). Will show the time of when the bookmark was last updated. 'echo' - Default is 1 (integer). Whether to echo (default) or return the formatted bookmarks. 'categorize' - Default is 1 (integer). Whether to show links listed by category (default) or show links in one column. 'show_description' - Default is 0 (integer). Whether to show the description of the bookmark.</p> <p>These options define how the Category name will appear before the category links are displayed, if 'categorize' is 1. If 'categorize' is 0, then it will display for only the 'title_li' string and only if 'title_li' is not empty. 'title_li' - Default is 'Bookmarks' (translatable string). What to show before the links appear. 'title_before' - Default is '</p> <h2>' (string). The HTML or text to show before the 'title_li' string. 'title_after' - Default is '</h2> <p>' (string). The HTML or text to show after the 'title_li' string. 'class' - Default is 'linkcat' (string). The CSS class to use for the 'title_li'.</p> <p>'category_before' - Default is '<li id="%id" class="%class">'. String must contain '%id' and '%class' to get the id of the category and the 'class' argument. These are used for formatting in themes. Argument will be displayed before the 'title_before' argument. 'category_after' - Default is '</li>' (string). The HTML or text that will appear after the list of links.</p> <p>These are only used if 'categorize' is set to 1 or true. 'category_orderby' - Default is 'name'. How to order the bookmark category based on term scheme. 'category_order' - Default is 'ASC'. Set the order by either ASC (ascending) or DESC (descending).</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\_walk_bookmarks()</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\get_bookmarks()</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>link</th> <td><a href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags/wp_list_bookmarks">http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags/wp_list_bookmarks</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.1.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\_list_bookmarks()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\get_terms()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>string</code><code>array</code><p>Optional. Overwrite the defaults of the function</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code><code>null</code>Will only return if echo option is set to not echo. Default is not return anything.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_list_categories"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_list_categories" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_list_categories .collapse"> <h2>Display or retrieve the HTML list of categories.</h2> <pre>wp_list_categories(string | array $args) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The list of arguments is below: 'show_option_all' (string) - Text to display for showing all categories. 'orderby' (string) default is 'ID' - What column to use for ordering the categories. 'order' (string) default is 'ASC' - What direction to order categories. 'show_count' (bool|int) default is 0 - Whether to show how many posts are in the category. 'hide_empty' (bool|int) default is 1 - Whether to hide categories that don't have any posts attached to them. 'use_desc_for_title' (bool|int) default is 1 - Whether to use the description instead of the category title. 'feed' - See <a href="get_categories()">get_categories()</a>. 'feed_type' - See <a href="get_categories()">get_categories()</a>. 'feed_image' - See <a href="get_categories()">get_categories()</a>. 'child_of' (int) default is 0 - See <a href="get_categories()">get_categories()</a>. 'exclude' (string) - See <a href="get_categories()">get_categories()</a>. 'exclude_tree' (string) - See <a href="get_categories()">get_categories()</a>. 'echo' (bool|int) default is 1 - Whether to display or retrieve content. 'current_category' (int) - See <a href="get_categories()">get_categories()</a>. 'hierarchical' (bool) - See <a href="get_categories()">get_categories()</a>. 'title_li' (string) - See <a href="get_categories()">get_categories()</a>. 'depth' (int) - The max depth.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.1.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>string</code><code>array</code><p>Optional. Override default arguments.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>HTML content only if 'echo' argument is 0.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_list_cats"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_list_cats" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_list_cats .collapse"> <h2>wp_list_cats() </h2> <pre>wp_list_cats(string | array $args) : \unknown</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.2</td> </tr> <tr> <th>deprecated</th> <td>2.1</td> </tr> <tr> <th>deprecated</th> <td>Use wp_list_categories()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\wp_list_categories()</a></td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>string</code><code>array</code> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"><code>\unknown</code></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_list_comments"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_list_comments" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_list_comments .collapse"> <h2>List comments</h2> <pre>wp_list_comments(string | array $args, array $comments) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Used in the comments.php template to list comments for a particular post</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\Walker_Comment</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>string</code><code>array</code><p>Formatting options</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$comments</h4> <code>array</code><p>Optional array of comment objects. Defaults to $wp_query->comments</p> </div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_list_filter"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_list_filter" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_list_filter .collapse"> <h2>Filters a list of objects, based on a set of key => value arguments.</h2> <pre>wp_list_filter(array $list, array $args, string $operator) : array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>3.1.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$list</h4> <code>array</code><p>An array of objects to filter</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><p>An array of key => value arguments to match against each object</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$operator</h4> <code>string</code><p>The logical operation to perform: 'AND' means all elements from the array must match; 'OR' means only one element needs to match; 'NOT' means no elements may match. The default is 'AND'.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"><code>array</code></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_list_pages"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_list_pages" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_list_pages .collapse"> <h2>Retrieve or display list of pages in list (li) format.</h2> <pre>wp_list_pages(array | string $args) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.5.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><code>string</code><p>Optional. (string) format : 'list' or 'form-table'. 'list' outputs UL, 'form-table' outputs TABLE with UI. (int) right : what revision is currently being viewed - used in form-table format. (int) left : what revision is currently being diffed against right - used in form-table format.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a Works only if the script has already been added. Accepts an associative array $l10n and creates JS object: "$object_name" = { key: value, key: value, ... } See http://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/11520 for more information.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>r16</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$handle</h4> <code>string</code><p>The script handle that was registered or used in script-loader</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$object_name</h4> <code>string</code><p>Name for the created JS object. This is passed directly so it should be qualified JS variable /[a-zA-Z0-9_]+/</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$l10n</h4> <code>array</code><p>Associative PHP array containing the translated strings. HTML entities will be converted and the array will be JSON encoded.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code>Whether the localization was added successfully.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_login"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_login" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_login .collapse"> <h2>Checks a users login information and logs them in if it checks out.</h2> <pre>wp_login(string $username, string $password, bool $deprecated) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This function is deprecated.</p> <p>Use the global $error to get the reason why the login failed. If the username is blank, no error will be set, so assume blank username on that case.</p> <p>Plugins extending this function should also provide the global $error and set what the error is, so that those checking the global for why there was a failure can utilize it later.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.2.2</td> </tr> <tr> <th>deprecated</th> <td>Use wp_signon()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>global</th> <td>string $error Error when false is returned</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$username</h4> <code>string</code><p>User's username</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$password</h4> <code>string</code><p>User's password</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$deprecated</h4> <code>bool</code><p>Not used</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code>False on login failure, true on successful check</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_login_form"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_login_form" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_login_form .collapse"> <h2>Provides a simple login form for use anywhere within WordPress.</h2> <pre>wp_login_form(array $args) : \Void,</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>By default, it echoes the HTML immediately. class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.5.0</td> </tr></table> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_logout_url"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_logout_url" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_logout_url .collapse"> <h2>Returns the Log Out URL.</h2> <pre>wp_logout_url(string $redirect) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Returns the URL that allows the user to log out of the site</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\wp_nonce_url()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> data-target=".function_wp_lostpassword_url .collapse"> <h2>Returns the Lost Password URL.</h2> <pre>wp_lostpassword_url(string $redirect) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Returns the URL that allows the user to retrieve the lost password</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.8.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\site_url()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$redirect</h4> <code>string</code><p>Path to redirect to on login.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_mail"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_mail" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_mail .collapse"> <h2>Send mail, similar to PHP's mail</h2> <pre>wp_mail(string | array $to, string $subject, string $message, string | array $headers, string | array $attachments) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>A true return value does not automatically mean that the user received the email successfully. It just only means that the method used was able to process the request without any errors.</p> <p>Using the two 'wp_mail_from' and 'wp_mail_from_name' hooks allow from creating a from address like 'Name <a href="mailto:email@address.com">email@address.com</a>' when both are set. If just 'wp_mail_from' is set, then just the email address will be used with no name.</p> <p>The default content type is 'text/plain' which does not allow using HTML. However, you can set the content type of the email by using the 'wp_mail_content_type' filter.</p> <p>The default charset is based on the charset used on the blog. The charset can be set using the 'wp_mail_charset' filter.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.2.1</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action_ref_array()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\PHPMailer</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$to</h4> <code>string</code><code>array</code><p>Array or comma-separated list of email addresses to send message.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$subject</h4> <code>string</code><p>Email subject</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$message</h4> <code>string</code><p>Message contents</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$headers</h4> <code>string</code><code>array</code><p>Optional. Additional headers.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$attachments</h4> <code>string</code><code>array</code><p>Optional. Files to attach.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code>Whether the email contents were sent successfully.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_make_link_relative"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_make_link_relative" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_make_link_relative .collapse"> <h2>Convert full URL paths to absolute paths.</h2> <pre>wp_make_link_relative(string $link) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Removes the http or https protocols and the domain. Keeps the path '/' at the beginning, so it isn't a true relative link, but from the web root base.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.1.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$link</h4> <code>string</code><p>Full URL path.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Absolute path.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_match_mime_types"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_match_mime_types" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_match_mime_types .collapse"> <h2>Check a MIME-Type against a list.</h2> <pre>wp_match_mime_types(string | array $wildcard_mime_types, string | array $real_mime_types) : array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>If the wildcard_mime_types parameter is a string, it must be comma separated list. If the real_mime_types is a string, it is also comma separated to create the list.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.5.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$wildcard_mime_types</h4> <code>string</code><code>array</code><p>e.g. audio/mpeg or image (same as image/<em>) or flash (same as *flash</em>).</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$real_mime_types</h4> <code>string</code><code>array</code><p>post_mime_type values</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>array</code>array(wildcard=>array(real types))</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_max_upload_size"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_max_upload_size" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_max_upload_size .collapse"> <h2>{@internal Missing Short Description}}</h2> <pre>wp_max_upload_size() : \unknown</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.5.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"><code>\unknown</code></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_maybe_load_embeds"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_maybe_load_embeds" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_maybe_load_embeds .collapse"> <h2>Determines if default embed handlers should be loaded.</h2> <pre>wp_maybe_load_embeds() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Checks to make sure that the embeds library hasn't already been loaded. data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_mkdir_p .collapse"> <h2>Recursive directory creation based on full path.</h2> <pre>wp_mkdir_p(string $target) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Will attempt to set permissions on folders.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.1</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$target</h4> <code>string</code><p>Full path to attempt to create.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code>Whether the path was created. True if path already exists.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_nav_menu"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_nav_menu" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_nav_menu .collapse"> <h2>Displays a navigation menu.</h2> <pre>wp_nav_menu(array $args) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Optional $args contents:</p> <p>menu - The menu that is desired. Accepts (matching in order) id, slug, name. Defaults to blank. menu_class - CSS class to use for the ul element which forms the menu. Defaults to 'menu'. menu_id - The ID that is applied to the ul element which forms the menu. Defaults to the menu slug, incremented. container - Whether to wrap the ul, and what to wrap it with. Defaults to 'div'. container_class - the class that is applied to the container. Defaults to 'menu-{menu slug}-container'. container_id - The ID that is applied to the container. Defaults to blank. fallback_cb - If the menu doesn't exists, a callback function will fire. Defaults to 'wp_page_menu'. Set to false for no fallback. before - Text before the link text. after - Text after the link text. link_before - Text before the link. link_after - Text after the link. echo - Whether to echo the menu or return it. Defaults to echo. depth - how many levels of the hierarchy are to be included. 0 means all. Defaults to 0. walker - allows a custom walker to be specified. theme_location - the location in the theme to be used. Must be registered with register_nav_menu() in order to be selectable by the user. items_wrap - How the list items should be wrapped. Defaults to a ul with an id and class. Uses printf() format with numbered placeholders.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>3.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><p>Arguments</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_nav_menu_item_link_meta_box"></a><div class="element clickable function class="long_description"><p></p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.1.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$blog_title</h4> <code>int</code><p>User ID.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$password</h4> <code>string</code><p>User's Password.</p> </div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_new_comment"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_new_comment" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_new_comment .collapse"> <h2>Adds a new comment to the database.</h2> <pre>wp_new_comment(array $commentdata) : int</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Filters new comment to ensure that the fields are sanitized and valid before inserting comment into database. Calls 'comment_post' action with comment ID and whether comment is approved by WordPress. Also has 'preprocess_comment' filter for processing the comment data before the function handles it.</p> <p>We use REMOTE_ADDR here directly. If you are behind a proxy, you should ensure that it is properly set, such as in wp-config.php, for your environment. See <a href="http://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/9235">http://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/9235</a></p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.5.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\wp_filter_comment()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\wp_allow_comment()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\wp_insert_comment()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$commentdata</h4> <code>array</code><p>Contains information on the comment.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>int</code>The ID of the comment after adding.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_new_user_notification"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_new_user_notification" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_new_user_notification .collapse"> <h2>Notify the blog admin of a new user, normally via email.</h2> <pre>wp_new_user_notification(int $user_id, string $plaintext_pass) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$user_id</h4> <code>int</code><p>User ID</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$plaintext_pass</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. The user's plaintext password</p> </div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_next_scheduled"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_next_scheduled" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_next_scheduled .collapse"> <h2>Retrieve the next timestamp for a cron event.</h2> <pre>wp_next_scheduled(string $hook, array $args) : bool | int</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.1.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$hook</h4> <code>string</code><p>Action hook to execute when cron is run.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><p>Optional. Arguments to pass to the hook's callback function.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code><code>int</code>The UNIX timestamp of the next time the scheduled event will occur.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_no_robots"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_no_robots" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_no_robots .collapse"> <h2>Display a noindex meta tag.</h2> <pre>wp_no_robots() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Outputs a noindex meta tag that tells web robots not to index the page content. Typical usage is as a wp_head callback. add_action( 'wp_head', 'wp_no_robots' );</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>3.3.0</td> </tr></table> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_nonce_ays"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_nonce_ays" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_nonce_ays .collapse"> <h2>Display "Are You Sure" message to confirm the action being taken.</h2> <pre>wp_nonce_ays(string $action) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>If the action has the nonce explain message, then it will be displayed along with the "Are you sure?" message.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Security.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Security</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.4</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$action</h4> <code>string</code><p>The nonce action.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_nonce_field"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_nonce_field" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_nonce_field .collapse"> <h2>Retrieve or display nonce hidden field for forms.</h2> <pre>wp_nonce_field(string $action, string $name, bool $referer, bool $echo) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The nonce field is used to validate that the contents of the form came from the location on the current site and not somewhere else. The nonce does not offer absolute protection, but should protect against most cases. It is very important to use nonce field in forms.</p> <p>The $action and $name are optional, but if you want to have better security, it is strongly suggested to set those two parameters. It is easier to just call the function without any parameters, because validation of the nonce doesn't require any parameters, but since crackers know what the default is it won't be difficult for them to find a way around your nonce and cause damage.</p> <p>The input name will be whatever $name value you gave. The input value will be the nonce creation value.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Security.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Security</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.4</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$action</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. Action name.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$name</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. Nonce name.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$referer</h4> <code>bool</code><p>Optional, default true. Whether to set the referer field for validation.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$echo</h4> <code>bool</code><p>Optional, default true. Whether to display or return hidden form field.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Nonce field.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_nonce_tick"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_nonce_tick" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_nonce_tick .collapse"> <h2>Get the time-dependent variable for nonce creation.</h2> <pre>wp_nonce_tick() : int</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>A nonce has a lifespan of two ticks. Nonces in their second tick may be updated, e.g. by autosave.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.5</td> </tr></table> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"><code>int</code></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_nonce_url"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_nonce_url" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_nonce_url .collapse"> <h2>Retrieve URL with nonce added to URL query.</h2> <pre>wp_nonce_url(string $actionurl, string $action) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Security.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Security</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.4</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$actionurl</h4> <code>string</code><p>URL to add nonce action</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$action</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. Nonce action name</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>URL with nonce action added.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_notify_moderator"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_notify_moderator" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_notify_moderator .collapse"> <h2>Notifies the moderator of the blog about a new comment that is awaiting approval.</h2> <pre>wp_notify_moderator(int $comment_id) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$wpdb</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$comment_id</h4> <code>int</code><p>Comment ID</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code>Always returns true</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_notify_postauthor"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_notify_postauthor" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_notify_postauthor .collapse"> <h2>Notify an author of a comment/trackback/pingback to one of their posts.</h2> <pre>wp_notify_postauthor(int $comment_id, string $comment_type) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$comment_id</h4> <code>int</code><p>Comment ID</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$comment_type</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. True on completion.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_ob_end_flush_all"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_ob_end_flush_all" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_ob_end_flush_all .collapse"> <h2>Flush all output buffers for PHP 5.2.</h2> <pre>wp_ob_end_flush_all() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Make sure all output buffers are flushed before our singletons our destroyed.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.2.0</td> </tr></table> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_oembed_add_provider"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_oembed_add_provider" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_oembed_add_provider .collapse"> <h2>Adds a URL format and oEmbed provider URL pair.</h2> <pre>wp_oembed_add_provider(string $format, string $provider, boolean $regex) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.9.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\WP_oEmbed</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\_wp_oembed_get_object()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$format</h4> <code>string</code><p>The format of URL that this provider can handle. class="element clickable function function_wp_original_referer_field" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_original_referer_field .collapse"> <h2>Retrieve or display original referer hidden field for forms.</h2> <pre>wp_original_referer_field(bool $echo, string $jump_back_to) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The input name is '_wp_original_http_referer' and will be either the same value of <a href="wp_referer_field()">wp_referer_field()</a>, if that was posted already or it will be the current page, if it doesn't exist.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Security.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Security</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.4</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$echo</h4> <code>bool</code><p>Whether to echo Check that function for more info on those arguments.</p> <ul> <li><strong>sort_column</strong> - How to sort the list of pages. Defaults to page title. Use column for posts table.</li> <li><strong>menu_class</strong> - Class to use for the div ID which contains the page list. Defaults to 'menu'.</li> <li><strong>echo</strong> - Whether to echo list or return it. Defaults to echo.</li> <li><strong>link_before</strong> - Text before show_home argument text.</li> <li><strong>link_after</strong> - Text after show_home argument text.</li> <li><strong>show_home</strong> - If you set this argument, then it will display the link to the home page. The show_home argument really just needs to be set to the value of the text of the link.</li> </ul></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7.0</td> </tr></table> function_wp_print_editor_js" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_print_editor_js .collapse"> <h2>wp_print_editor_js() </h2> <pre>wp_print_editor_js() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>deprecated</th> <td>3.3.0</td> </tr> <tr> footer.</h2> <pre>wp_print_footer_scripts() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.8</td> </tr></table> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_print_head_scripts"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_print_head_scripts" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_print_head_scripts .collapse"> <h2>Prints the script queue in the HTML head on the front end.</h2> <pre>wp_print_head_scripts() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Postpones the scripts that were queued for the footer. wp_print_footer_scripts() is called in the footer to print these scripts.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.8</td> </tr></table> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_print_scripts"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_print_scripts" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_print_scripts .collapse"> <h2>Prints script tags in document head.</h2> <pre>wp_print_scripts($handles) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Called by admin-header.php and by wp_head hook. Since it is called by wp_head on every page load, the function does not instantiate the WP_Scripts object unless script names are explicitly passed. Does make use of already instantiated $wp_scripts if present. Use provided wp_print_scripts hook to register/enqueue new scripts.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>r16</td> </tr> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\WP_Dependencies::print_scripts()</a></td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"><h4>$handles</h4></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_print_styles"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_print_styles" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_print_styles .collapse"> <h2>Display styles that are in the queue or part of $handles.</h2> <pre>wp_print_styles(array | bool $handles) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>r79</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>global</th> <td>object $wp_styles The WP_Styles object for printing styles.</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$handles</h4> <code>array</code><code>bool</code><p>Styles to be printed. An empty array prints the queue, an array with one string prints that style, and an array of strings prints those styles.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code>True on success, false on failure.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_protect_special_option"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_protect_special_option" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_protect_special_option .collapse"> <h2>Protect WordPress special option from being modified.</h2> <pre>wp_protect_special_option(string $option) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Will die if $option is in protected list. Protected options are 'alloptions' and 'notoptions' options.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.2.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a
