id="function_wp_rand"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_rand" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_rand .collapse"> <h2>Generates a random number</h2> <pre>wp_rand(int $min, int $max) : int</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.6.2</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$min</h4> <code>int</code><p>Lower limit for the generated number (optional, default is 0)</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$max</h4> <code>int</code><p>Upper limit for the generated number (optional, default is 4294967295)</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>int</code>A random number between min and max</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_read_image_metadata"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_read_image_metadata" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_read_image_metadata .collapse"> <h2>Get extended image metadata, exif or iptc as available.</h2> <pre>wp_read_image_metadata(string $file) : bool | array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Retrieves the EXIF metadata aperture, credit, camera, caption, copyright, iso created_timestamp, focal_length, shutter_speed, and title.</p> <p>The IPTC metadata that is retrieved is APP13, credit, byline, created date and time, caption, copyright, and title. Also includes FNumber, Model, DateTimeDigitized, FocalLength, ISOSpeedRatings, and ExposureTime.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>todo</th> <td>Try other exif libraries if available.</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.5.0</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$file</h4> <code>string</code> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code><code>array</code>False on failure. Image metadata array on success.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_redirect"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_redirect" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_redirect .collapse"> <h2>Redirects to another page.</h2> <pre>wp_redirect(string $location, int $status) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.5.1</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$location</h4> <code>string</code><p>The path to redirect to</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$status</h4> <code>int</code><p>Status code to use</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code>False if $location is not set</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_redirect_admin_locations"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_redirect_admin_locations" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_redirect_admin_locations .collapse"> <h2>wp_redirect_admin_locations() </h2> <pre>wp_redirect_admin_locations() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"><div class="long_description"></div></div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_referer_field"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_referer_field" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_referer_field .collapse"> <h2>Retrieve or display referer hidden field for forms.</h2> <pre>wp_referer_field(bool $echo) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The referer link is the current Request URI from the server super global. Example: '/css/mystyle.css'.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$deps</h4> <code>array</code><p>Array of handles of any stylesheet that this stylesheet depends on. (Stylesheets that must be loaded before this stylesheet.) Pass an empty array if there are no dependencies.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$ver</h4> <code>string</code><code>bool</code><p>String specifying the stylesheet version number. Set to null to disable. Used to ensure that the correct version is sent to the client regardless of caching.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$media</h4> <code>string</code><p>The media for which this stylesheet has been defined.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_register_widget_control"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_register_widget_control" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_register_widget_control .collapse"> <h2>Registers widget control callback for customizing options.</h2> <pre>wp_register_widget_control(int | string $id, string $name, callback $control_callback, array | string $options) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The options contains the 'height', 'width', and 'id_base' keys. The 'height' option is never used. The 'width' option is the width of the fully expanded control form, but try hard to use the default width. The 'id_base' is for multi-widgets (widgets which allow multiple instances such as the text widget), an id_base must be provided. The widget id will end up looking like {$id_base}-{$unique_number}.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.2.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$id</h4> <code>int</code><code>string</code><p>Sidebar ID.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$name</h4> <code>string</code><p>Sidebar display name.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$control_callback</h4> <code>callback</code><p>Run when sidebar is displayed.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$options</h4> <code>array</code><code>string</code><p>Optional. Widget options. See above long description.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_rel_nofollow"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_rel_nofollow" data-toggle="collapse" Override the defaults.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code><a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></code><code>array</code>The response or WP_Error on failure.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_remote_head"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_remote_head" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_remote_head .collapse"> <h2>Retrieve the raw response from the HTTP request using the HEAD method.</h2> <pre>wp_remote_head(string $url, array $args) : <a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a> | array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\wp_remote_request()</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7.0</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$url</h4> <code>string</code><p>Site URL to retrieve.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><p>Optional. Override the defaults.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code><a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></code><code>array</code>The response or WP_Error on failure.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_remote_post"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_remote_post" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_remote_post .collapse"> <h2>Retrieve the raw response from the HTTP request using the POST method.</h2> <pre>wp_remote_post(string $url, array $args) : <a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a> | array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\wp_remote_request()</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7.0</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$url</h4> <code>string</code><p>Site URL to retrieve.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><p>Optional. Override the defaults.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code><a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></code><code>array</code>The response or WP_Error on failure.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_remote_request"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_remote_request" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_remote_request .collapse"> <h2>Retrieve the raw response from the HTTP request.</h2> <pre>wp_remote_request(string $url, array $args) : <a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a> | array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The array structure is a little complex.</p> <pre><code>$res = array( 'headers' => array(), 'response' => array('code' => int, 'message' => string) ); </code></pre> <p>All of the headers in $res['headers'] are with the name as the key and the value as the value. So to get the User-Agent, you would do the following.</p> <pre><code>$user_agent = $res['headers']['user-agent']; </code></pre> <p>The body is the raw response content and can be retrieved from $res['body'].</p> <p>This function is called first to make the request and there are other API functions to abstract out the above convoluted setup.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$url</h4> <code>string</code><p>Site URL to retrieve.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><p>Optional. Override the defaults.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code><a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></code><code>array</code>The response or WP_Error on failure.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_remote_retrieve_body"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_remote_retrieve_body" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_remote_retrieve_body .collapse"> <h2>Retrieve only the body from the raw response.</h2> <pre>wp_remote_retrieve_body(array $response) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$response</h4> <code>array</code><p>HTTP response.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>The body of the response. Empty string if no body or incorrect parameter given.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_remote_retrieve_header"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_remote_retrieve_header" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_remote_retrieve_header .collapse"> <h2>Retrieve a single header by name from the raw response.</h2> <pre>wp_remote_retrieve_header(array $response, string $header) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$response</h4> <code>array</code> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$header</h4> <code>string</code><p>Header name to retrieve value from.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>The header value. Empty string on if incorrect parameter given, or if the header doesn't exist.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_remote_retrieve_headers"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_remote_retrieve_headers" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_remote_retrieve_headers .collapse"> <h2>Retrieve only the headers from the raw response.</h2> <pre>wp_remote_retrieve_headers(array $response) : array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$response</h4> <code>array</code><p>HTTP response.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>array</code>The headers of the response. Empty array if incorrect parameter given.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_remote_retrieve_response_code"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_remote_retrieve_response_code" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_remote_retrieve_response_code .collapse"> <h2>Retrieve only the response code from the raw response.</h2> <pre>wp_remote_retrieve_response_code(array $response) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Will return an empty array if incorrect parameter value is given.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$response</h4> <code>array</code><p>HTTP response.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>the response code. id="function_wp_restore_post_revision"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_restore_post_revision" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_restore_post_revision .collapse"> <h2>Restores a post to the specified revision.</h2> <pre>wp_restore_post_revision(int | object $revision_id, array $fields) : mixed</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Can restore a past revision using all fields of the post revision, or only selected fields.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Post.Revisions.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Post_Revisions</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.6.0</td> </tr> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$revision_id</h4> <code>int</code><code>object</code><p>Revision ID or revision object.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$fields</h4> <code>array</code><p>Optional. What fields to restore from. Defaults to all.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>mixed</code>Null if error, false if no fields to restore, (int) post ID if success.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_revoke_user"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_revoke_user" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_revoke_user .collapse"> <h2>Remove all capabilities from user.</h2> <pre>wp_revoke_user(int $id) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.1.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$id</h4> <code>int</code><p>User ID.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_richedit_pre"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_richedit_pre" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_richedit_pre .collapse"> <h2>Formats text for the rich text editor.</h2> <pre>wp_richedit_pre(string $text) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The filter 'richedit_pre' is applied here. If $text is empty the filter will be applied to an empty string.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$text</h4> <code>string</code><p>The text to be formatted.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>The formatted text after filter is applied.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_rss"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_rss" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_rss .collapse"> <h2>Display all RSS items in a HTML ordered list.</h2> <pre>wp_rss(string $url, int $num_items) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.5.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/External.MagpieRSS.html">External</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>MagpieRSS</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$url</h4> <code>string</code><p>URL of feed to display. Will not auto sense feed URL.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$num_items</h4> <code>int</code><p>Optional. Number of items to display, default is all.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_safe_redirect"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_safe_redirect" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_safe_redirect .collapse"> <h2>Performs a safe (local) redirect, using wp_redirect().</h2> <pre>wp_safe_redirect($location, $status) : void</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Checks whether the $location is using an allowed host, if it has an absolute path. A plugin can therefore set or remove allowed host(s) to or from the list.</p> <p>If the host is not allowed, then the redirect is to wp-admin on the siteurl instead. This prevents malicious redirects which redirect to another host, but only used in a few places.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\wp_validate_redirect()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"><h4>$location</h4></div> <div class="subelement argument"><h4>$status</h4></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_salt"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_salt" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_salt .collapse"> <h2>Get salt to add to hashes.</h2> <pre>wp_salt(string $scheme) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Salts are created using secret keys. Secret keys are located in two places: in the database and in the wp-config.php file. The secret key in the database is randomly generated and will be appended to the secret keys in wp-config.php.</p> <p>The secret keys in wp-config.php should be updated to strong, random keys to maximize security. Below is an example of how the secret key constants are defined. Do not paste this example directly into wp-config.php. Instead, have a <a href="https://api.wordpress.org/secret-key/1.1/salt/">secret key created</a> just for you.</p> <pre><code>define('AUTH_KEY', ' Xakm<o xQy rw4EMsLKM-?!T+,PFF})H4lzcW57AF0U@N@< >M%G4Yt>f`z]MON'); define('SECURE_AUTH_KEY', 'LzJ}op]mr|6+![P}Ak:uNdJCJZd>(Hx.-Mh#Tz)pCIU#uGEnfFz|f ;;eU%/U^O~'); define('LOGGED_IN_KEY', '|i|Ux`9<p-h$aFf(qnT:sDO:D1P^wZ$$/Ra@miTJi9G;ddp_<q}6H1)o|a + define('NONCE_KEY', '%:R{[P|,s.KuMltH5}cI;/k<Gx~j!f0I)m_sIyu+ define('AUTH_SALT', 'eZyT)-Naw]F8CwA*VaW#q*|.)g@o}||wf~@C-YSt}(dh_r6EbI#A,y|nU2{B#JBW'); define('SECURE_AUTH_SALT', '!=oLUTXh,QW=H `}`L|9/^4-3 STz},T(w}W<I`.JjPi)<Bmf1v,HpGe}T1:Xt7n'); define('LOGGED_IN_SALT', '+XSqHc;@Q*K_b|Z?NC[3H!!EONbh.n<+=uKR:>*c(u`g~EJBf#8u#R{mUEZrozmm'); define('NONCE_SALT', 'h`GXHhD>SLWVfg1(1(N{;.V!MoE(SfbA_ksP@ </code></pre> <p>Salting passwords helps against tools which has stored hashed values of common dictionary strings. The added values makes it harder to crack.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.5</td> </tr> <tr> <th>link</th> <td><a href="https://api.wordpress.org/secret-key/1.1/salt/">Create secrets for wp-config.php</a></td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$scheme</h4> <code>string</code><p>Authentication scheme (auth, secure_auth, logged_in, nonce)</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Salt value</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_sanitize_redirect"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_sanitize_redirect" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_sanitize_redirect .collapse"> function_wp_save_post_revision" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_save_post_revision .collapse"> <h2>Saves an already existing post as a post revision.</h2> <pre>wp_save_post_revision(int $post_id) : mixed</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Typically used immediately prior to post updates.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Post.Revisions.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Post_Revisions</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.6.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\_wp_put_post_revision()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> success.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_schedule_event"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_schedule_event" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_schedule_event .collapse"> <h2>Schedule a periodic event.</h2> <pre>wp_schedule_event(int $timestamp, string $recurrence, string $hook, array $args) : bool | null</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Schedules a hook which will be executed by the WordPress actions core on a specific interval, specified by you. The action will trigger when someone visits your WordPress site, if the scheduled time has passed.</p> <p>Valid values for the recurrence are hourly, daily and twicedaily. These can be extended using the cron_schedules filter in wp_get_schedules().</p> <p>Use wp_next_scheduled() to prevent duplicates</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.1.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$timestamp</h4> <code>int</code><p>Timestamp for when to run the event.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$recurrence</h4> <code>string</code><p>How often the event should recur.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$hook</h4> <code>string</code><p>Action hook to execute when cron is run.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><p>Optional. Arguments to pass to the hook's callback function.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code><code>null</code>False on failure, null when complete with scheduling event.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_schedule_single_event"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_schedule_single_event" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_schedule_single_event .collapse"> <h2>Schedules a hook to run only once.</h2> <pre>wp_schedule_single_event(int $timestamp, string $hook, array $args) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Schedules a hook which will be executed once by the WordPress actions core at a time which you specify. The action will fire off when someone visits your WordPress site, if the schedule time has passed.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.1.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>link</th> <td><a href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Function_Reference/wp_schedule_single_event">http://codex.wordpress.org/Function_Reference/wp_schedule_single_event</a></td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$timestamp</h4> <code>int</code><p>Timestamp for when to run the event.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$hook</h4> <code>string</code><p>Action hook to execute when cron is run.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><p>Optional. Arguments to pass to the hook's callback function.</p> </div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_schedule_update_checks"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_schedule_update_checks" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_schedule_update_checks .collapse"> <h2>Schedule core, theme, and plugin update checks.</h2> function_wp_set_object_terms" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_set_object_terms .collapse"> <h2>Create Term and Taxonomy Relationships.</h2> <pre>wp_set_object_terms(int $object_id, array | int | string $terms, array | string $taxonomy, bool $append) : array | <a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Relates an object (post, link etc) to a term and taxonomy type. Creates the term and taxonomy relationship if it doesn't already exist. Creates a term if it doesn't exist (using the slug).</p> <p>A relationship means that the term is grouped in or belongs to the taxonomy. A term has no meaning until it is given context by defining which taxonomy it exists under.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Taxonomy.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Taxonomy</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$wpdb</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$object_id</h4> <code>int</code><p>The object to relate to.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$terms</h4> <code>array</code><code>int</code><code>string</code><p>The slug or id of the term, will replace all existing related terms in this taxonomy.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$taxonomy</h4> <code>array</code><code>string</code><p>The context in which to relate the term to the object.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$append</h4> <code>bool</code><p>If false will delete difference of terms.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>array</code><code><a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></code>Affected Term IDs</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_set_password"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_set_password" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_set_password The user's password</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$already_md5</h4> <code>bool</code><p>Optional. Whether the password has already been through MD5</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$home</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. Will be used instead of COOKIEPATH if set</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$siteurl</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. Will be used instead of SITECOOKIEPATH if set</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$remember</h4> <code>bool</code><p>Optional. Remember that the user is logged in</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_setup_nav_menu_item"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_setup_nav_menu_item" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_setup_nav_menu_item .collapse"> <h2>Decorates a menu item object with the shared navigation menu item properties.</h2> <pre>wp_setup_nav_menu_item(object $menu_item) : object</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Properties: - db_id: The DB ID of this item as a nav_menu_item object, if it exists (0 if it doesn't exist). - object_id: The DB ID of the original object this menu item represents, e.g. ID for posts and term_id for categories. - type: The family of objects originally represented, such as "post_type" or "taxonomy." - object: The type of object originally represented, such as "category," "post", or "attachment." - type_label: The singular label used to describe this type of menu item. - post_parent: The DB ID of the original object's parent object, if any (0 otherwise). - menu_item_parent: The DB ID of the nav_menu_item that is this item's menu parent, if any. 0 otherwise. - url: The URL to which this menu item points. - title: The title of this menu item. - target: The target attribute of the link element for this menu item. - attr_title: The title attribute of the link element for this menu item. - classes: The array of class attribute values for the link element of this menu item. - xfn: The XFN relationship expressed in the link of this menu item. - description: The description of this menu item.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>3.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$menu_item</h4> <code>object</code><p>The menu item to modify.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>object</code>$menu_item The menu item with standard menu item properties.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_shake_js"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_shake_js" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_shake_js .collapse"> <h2>wp_shake_js() </h2> <pre>wp_shake_js() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"><div class="long_description"></div></div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_shortlink_header"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_shortlink_header" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_shortlink_header .collapse"> <h2>Send a Link: rel=shortlink header if a shortlink is defined for the current page.</h2> <pre>wp_shortlink_header() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Attached to the wp action.</p></div> <table id="function_wp_specialchars_decode"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_specialchars_decode" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_specialchars_decode .collapse"> <h2>Converts a number of HTML entities into their special characters.</h2> <pre>wp_specialchars_decode(string $string, mixed $quote_style) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Specifically deals with: &, <, >, ", and '.</p> <p>$quote_style can be set to ENT_COMPAT to decode " entities, or ENT_QUOTES to do both " and '. Default is ENT_NOQUOTES where no quotes are decoded.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.8</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$string</h4> <code>string</code><p>The text which is to be decoded.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$quote_style</h4> <code>mixed</code><p>Optional. Converts double quotes if set to ENT_COMPAT, both single and double if set to ENT_QUOTES or none if set to ENT_NOQUOTES. Also compatible with old _wp_specialchars() values; converting single quotes if set to 'single', double if set to 'double' or both if otherwise set. Default is ENT_NOQUOTES.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>The decoded text without HTML entities.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_sprintf"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_sprintf" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_sprintf .collapse"> <h2>WordPress implementation of PHP sprintf() with filters.</h2> <pre>wp_sprintf(string $pattern) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.5.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>link</th> <td><a href="http://www.php.net/sprintf">http://www.php.net/sprintf</a></td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$pattern</h4> <code>string</code><p>The string which formatted args are inserted.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>The formatted string.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_sprintf_l"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_sprintf_l" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_sprintf_l .collapse"> <h2>Localize list items before the rest of the content.</h2> <pre>wp_sprintf_l(string $pattern, array $args) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The '%l' must be at the first characters can then contain the rest of the content. function function_wp_style_loader_src" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_style_loader_src .collapse"> <h2>Administration Screen CSS for changing the styles.</h2> <pre>wp_style_loader_src(string $src, string $handle) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>If installing the 'wp-admin/' directory will be replaced with './'.</p> <p>The $_wp_admin_css_colors global manages the Administration Screens CSS stylesheet that is loaded. The option that is set is 'admin_color' and is the color and key for the array. The value for the color key is an object with a 'url' parameter that has the URL path to the CSS file.</p> <p>The query from $src parameter will be appended to the URL that is given from the $_wp_admin_css_colors array value URL.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.6.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$_wp_admin_css_colors</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$src</h4> <code>string</code><p>Source URL.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$handle</h4> <code>string</code><p>Either 'colors' or 'colors-rtl'.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>URL path to CSS stylesheet for Administration Screens.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_suspend_cache_addition"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_suspend_cache_addition" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_suspend_cache_addition .collapse"> <h2>Temporarily suspend cache additions.</h2> <pre>wp_suspend_cache_addition(bool $suspend) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Stops more data being added to the cache, but still allows cache retrieval. This is useful for actions, such as imports, when a lot of data would otherwise be almost uselessly added to the cache.</p> <p>Suspension lasts for a single page load at most. Remember to call this function again if you wish to re-enable cache adds earlier.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>3.3.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$suspend</h4> <code>bool</code><p>Optional. Suspends additions if true, re-enables them if false.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code>The current suspend setting</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_suspend_cache_invalidation"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_suspend_cache_invalidation" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_suspend_cache_invalidation .collapse"> <h2>Suspend cache invalidation.</h2> <pre>wp_suspend_cache_invalidation(bool $suspend) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Turns cache invalidation on and off. Useful during imports where you don't wont to do invalidations every time a post is inserted. Callers must be sure that what they are doing won't lead to an inconsistent cache when invalidation is suspended.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$suspend</h4> <code>bool</code><p>Whether to suspend or enable cache invalidation</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code>The current suspend setting</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_tag_cloud"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_tag_cloud" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_tag_cloud .collapse"> <h2>Display tag cloud.</h2> <pre>wp_tag_cloud(array | string $args) : array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The text size is set by the 'smallest' and 'largest' arguments, which will use the 'unit' argument value for the CSS text size unit. The 'format' argument can be 'flat' (default), 'list', or 'array'. The flat value for the 'format' argument will separate tags with spaces. The list value for the 'format' argument will format the tags in a UL HTML list. The array value for the 'format' argument will return in PHP array type format.</p> <p>The 'orderby' argument will accept 'name' or 'count' and defaults to 'name'. The 'order' is the direction to sort, defaults to 'ASC' and can be 'DESC'.</p> <p>The 'number' argument is how many tags to return. By default, the limit will be to return the top 45 tags in the tag cloud list.</p> <p>The 'topic_count_text_callback' argument is a function, which, given the count of the posts with that tag, returns a text for the tooltip of the tag link.</p> <p>The 'exclude' and 'include' arguments are used for the <a href="get_tags()">get_tags()</a> function. Only one should be used, because only one will be used and the other ignored, if they are both set.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><code>string</code><p>Optional. Override default arguments.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>array</code>Generated tag cloud, only if no failures and 'array' is set for the 'format' argument.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_templating_constants"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_templating_constants" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_templating_constants .collapse"> <h2>Defines templating related WordPress constants</h2> <pre>wp_templating_constants() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row directory can either be passed as well, or by leaving it blank, default to a writable temporary directory.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.6.0</td> <code>array</code> </div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_text_diff"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_text_diff" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_text_diff .collapse"> <h2>Displays a human readable HTML representation of the difference between two strings.</h2> <pre>wp_text_diff(string $left_string, string $right_string, string | array $args) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The Diff is available for getting the changes between versions. The output is HTML, so the primary use is for displaying the changes. If the two strings are equivalent, then an empty string will be returned.</p> <p>The arguments supported and can be changed are listed below.</p> <p>'title' : Default is an empty string. Titles the diff in a manner compatible with the output. 'title_left' : Default is an empty string. Change the HTML to the left of the title. 'title_right' : Default is an empty string. Change the HTML to the right of the title.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.6</td> </tr> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\wp_parse_args()</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\Text_Diff</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\WP_Text_Diff_Renderer_Table</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$left_string</h4> <code>string</code><p>"old" (left) version of string</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$right_string</h4> <code>string</code><p>"new" (right) version of string</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>string</code><code>array</code><p>Optional. Change 'title', 'title_left', and 'title_right' defaults.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Empty string if strings are equivalent or HTML with differences.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_theme_update_row"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_theme_update_row" data-toggle="collapse" </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_theme_update_rows"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_theme_update_rows" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_theme_update_rows class="long_description"></div></div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_throttle_comment_flood"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_throttle_comment_flood" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_throttle_comment_flood .collapse"> <h2>Whether comment should be blocked because of comment flood.</h2> <pre>wp_throttle_comment_flood(bool $block, int $time_lastcomment, int $time_newcomment) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> formatted list of timezone strings.</h2> <pre>wp_timezone_choice(string $selected_zone) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>// temporary! class="element clickable function function_wp_timezone_override_offset" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_timezone_override_offset .collapse"> <h2>gmt_offset modification for smart timezone handling.</h2> <pre>wp_timezone_override_offset() : float | bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.9.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>deprecated</th> <td>3.2.0</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"><code>bool</code></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_tiny_mce"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_tiny_mce" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_tiny_mce .collapse"> <h2>wp_tiny_mce() </h2> <pre>wp_tiny_mce($teeny, $settings) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>deprecated</th> <td>3.3</td> </tr> <tr> <th>deprecated</th> <td>Use wp_editor()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\wp_editor()</a></td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"><h4>$teeny</h4></div> <div class="subelement argument"><h4>$settings</h4></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_title"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_title" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_title .collapse"> <h2>Display or retrieve page title for all areas of blog.</h2> <pre>wp_title(string $sep, bool $display, string $seplocation) : string | null</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>By default, the page title will display the separator before the page title, so that the blog title will be before the page title. This is not good for title display, since the blog title shows up on most tabs and not what is important, which is the page that the user is looking at.</p> <p>There are also SEO benefits to having the blog title after or to the 'right' or the page title. However, it is mostly common sense to have the blog title to the right with most browsers supporting tabs. You can achieve this by using the seplocation parameter and setting the value to 'right'. This change was introduced around 2.5.0, in case backwards compatibility of themes is important.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$sep</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional, default is ''. How to separate the various items within the page title.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$display</h4> <code>bool</code><p>Optional, default is true. Whether to display or retrieve title.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$seplocation</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. Direction to display title, 'right'.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code><code>null</code>String on retrieve, null when displaying.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_title_rss"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_title_rss" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_title_rss .collapse"> <h2>Display the blog title for display of the feed title.</h2> <pre>wp_title_rss(string $sep) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Feed.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Feed</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.2.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\wp_title()</a></td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$sep</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_transition_comment_status"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_transition_comment_status" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_transition_comment_status .collapse"> <h2>Call hooks for when a comment status transition occurs.</h2> <pre>wp_transition_comment_status(string $new_status, string $old_status, object $comment) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Calls hooks for comment status transitions. If the new comment status is not the same as the previous comment status, then two hooks will be ran, the first is 'transition_comment_status' with new status, old status, and comment data. The next action called is 'comment_OLDSTATUS_to_NEWSTATUS' the NEWSTATUS is the $new_status parameter and the OLDSTATUS is $old_status parameter; it has the comment data.</p> <p>The final action will run whether or not the comment statuses are the same. The action is named 'comment_NEWSTATUS_COMMENTTYPE', NEWSTATUS is from the $new_status parameter and COMMENTTYPE is comment_type comment data.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$new_status</h4> <code>string</code><p>New comment status.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$old_status</h4> <code>string</code><p>Previous comment status.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$comment</h4> <code>object</code><p>Comment data.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_transition_post_status"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_transition_post_status" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_transition_post_status .collapse"> <h2>Transition the post status of a post.</h2> <pre>wp_transition_post_status(string $new_status, string $old_status, object $post) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Calls hooks to transition post status.</p> <p>The first is 'transition_post_status' with new status, old status, and post data.</p> <p>The next action called is 'OLDSTATUS_to_NEWSTATUS' the 'NEWSTATUS' is the $new_status parameter and the 'OLDSTATUS' is $old_status parameter; it has the post data.</p> <p>The final action is named 'NEWSTATUS_POSTTYPE', 'NEWSTATUS' is from the $new_status parameter and POSTTYPE is post_type post data.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>link</th> <td><a href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Post_Status_Transitions">http://codex.wordpress.org/Post_Status_Transitions</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$new_status</h4> <code>string</code><p>Transition to this post status.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$old_status</h4> <code>string</code><p>Previous post status.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$post</h4> <code>object</code><p>Post data.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_trash_comment"></a><div class="element clickable </div> <a id="function_wp_trim_excerpt"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_trim_excerpt" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_trim_excerpt .collapse"> <h2>Generates an excerpt from the content, if needed.</h2> <pre>wp_trim_excerpt(string $text) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The excerpt word amount will be 55 words and if the amount is greater than that, then the string ' [...]' will be appended to the excerpt. If the string is less than 55 words, then the content will be returned as is.</p> <p>The 55 word limit can be modified by plugins/themes using the excerpt_length filter The ' [...]' string can be modified by plugins/themes using the excerpt_more filter</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.5.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$text</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. The excerpt. If set to empty, an excerpt is generated.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>The excerpt.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_trim_words"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_trim_words" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_trim_words .collapse"> <h2>Trims text to a certain number of words.</h2> <pre>wp_trim_words(string $text, int $num_words, string $more) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This function is localized. For languages that count 'words' by the individual character (such as East Asian languages), the $num_words argument will apply to the number of individual characters.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>3.3.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$text</h4> <code>string</code><p>Text to trim.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$num_words</h4> <code>int</code><p>Number of words. Default 55.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$more</h4> <code>string</code><p>What to append if $text needs to be trimmed. Default ''.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Trimmed text.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_unique_filename"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_unique_filename" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_unique_filename .collapse"> <h2>Get a filename that is sanitized and unique for the given directory.</h2> <pre>wp_unique_filename(string $dir, string $filename, mixed $unique_filename_callback) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>If the filename is not unique, then a number will be added to the filename before the extension, and will continue adding numbers until the filename is unique.</p> <p>The callback is passed three parameters, the first one is the directory, the second is the filename, and the third is the extension.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.5.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$dir</h4> <code>string</code> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> response"> <code>string</code>New filename, if given wasn't unique.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_unique_post_slug"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_unique_post_slug" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_unique_post_slug .collapse"> <h2>Computes a unique slug for the post, when given the desired slug and some post details.</h2> <pre>wp_unique_post_slug(string $slug, integer $post_ID, string $post_status, string $post_type, integer $post_parent) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.8.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>global</th> <td>wpdb $wpdb</td> </tr> <tr> <th>global</th> <td>WP_Rewrite $wp_rewrite</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$slug</h4> <code>string</code><p>the desired slug (post_name)</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$post_ID</h4> <code>integer</code> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$post_status</h4> <code>string</code><p>no uniqueness checks are made if <a id="function_wp_unique_term_slug"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_unique_term_slug" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_unique_term_slug .collapse"> <h2>Will make slug unique, if it isn't already.</h2> <pre>wp_unique_term_slug(string $slug, object $term) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The $slug has to be unique global to every taxonomy, meaning that one taxonomy term can't have a matching slug with another taxonomy term. Each slug has to be globally unique for every taxonomy.</p> <p>The way this works is that if the taxonomy that the term belongs to is hierarchical and has a parent, it will append that parent to the $slug.</p> <p>If that still doesn't return an unique slug, then it try to append a number until it finds a number that is truly unique.</p> <p>The only purpose for $term is for appending a parent, if one exists.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Taxonomy.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Taxonomy</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$wpdb</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$slug</h4> <code>string</code><p>The string that will be tried for a unique slug</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$term</h4> <code>object</code><p>The term object that the $slug will belong too</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Will return a true unique slug.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_unregister_sidebar_widget"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_unregister_sidebar_widget" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_unregister_sidebar_widget .collapse"> <h2>Remove widget from sidebar.</h2> <pre>wp_unregister_sidebar_widget(int | string $id) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.2.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$id</h4> <code>int</code><code>string</code><p>Widget ID.</p></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_unregister_widget_control"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_unregister_widget_control" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_unregister_widget_control </div> <a id="function_wp_unschedule_event"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_unschedule_event" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_unschedule_event .collapse"> <h2>Unschedule a previously scheduled cron job.</h2> <pre>wp_unschedule_event(int $timestamp, string $hook, array $args) </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The $timestamp and $hook parameters are required, so that the event can be identified.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.1.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$timestamp</h4> <code>int</code><p>Timestamp for when to run the event.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$hook</h4> <code>string</code><p>Action hook, the execution of which will be unscheduled.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><p>Arguments to pass to the hook's callback function. Although not passed to a callback function, these arguments are used to uniquely identify the scheduled event, so they should be the same as those used when originally scheduling the event.</p> </div> When $do_deferred is set to true, then all previous deferred post IDs will be updated along with the current $post_id.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.1.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\wp_update_comment_count_now()</a></td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$post_id</h4> <code>int</code><p>Post ID</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$do_deferred</h4> <code>bool</code><p>Whether to process previously deferred post comment counts</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code>True on success, false on failure</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_update_comment_count_now"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_update_comment_count_now" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_update_comment_count_now .collapse"> <h2>Updates the comment count for the post.</h2> <pre>wp_update_comment_count_now(int $post_id) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.5.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$wpdb</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$post_id</h4> <code>int</code><p>Post ID</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code>False on '0' $post_id or if post with ID does not exist. You can set the date and it will not be overridden.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>1.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$postarr</h4> <code>array</code><code>object</code><p>Post data. Arrays are expected to be escaped, objects are not.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>int</code>0 on failure, Post ID on success.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_update_term"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_update_term" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_update_term .collapse"> <h2>Update term based on arguments provided.</h2> <pre>wp_update_term(int $term_id, string $taxonomy, array | string $args) : array | <a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The $args will indiscriminately override all values with the same field name. Care must be taken to not override important information need to update or update will fail (or perhaps create a new term, neither would be acceptable).</p> <p>Defaults will set 'alias_of', 'description', 'parent', and 'slug' if not defined in $args already.</p> <p>'alias_of' will create a term group, if it doesn't already exist, and update it for the $term.</p> <p>If the 'slug' argument in $args is missing, then the 'name' in $args will be used. It should also be noted that if you set 'slug' and it isn't unique then a WP_Error will be passed back. If you don't pass any slug, then a unique one will be created for you.</p> <p>For what can be overrode in $args, check the term scheme can contain and stay away from the term keys.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Taxonomy.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Taxonomy</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.3.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\$wpdb</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\do_action()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$term_id</h4> <code>int</code><p>The ID of the term</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$taxonomy</h4> <code>string</code><p>The context in which to relate the term to the object.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$args</h4> <code>array</code><code>string</code><p>Overwrite term field values</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>array</code><code><a href="../classes/WP_Error.html">\WP_Error</a></code>Returns Term ID and Taxonomy Term ID</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_update_term_count"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_update_term_count" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_update_term_count .collapse"> <h2>Updates the amount of terms in taxonomy.</h2> <pre>wp_update_term_count(int | array $terms, string $taxonomy, $do_deferred) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>If there is a taxonomy callback applied, then it will be called for updating the count.</p> <p>The default action is to count what the amount of terms have the relationship of term ID. Once that is done, then update the database.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Taxonomy.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> return true.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_update_term_count_now"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_update_term_count_now" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_update_user .collapse"> <h2>Update an user in the database.</h2> <pre>wp_update_user(array $userdata) : int</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>It is possible to update a user's password by specifying the 'user_pass' value in the $userdata parameter array.</p> <p>If $userdata does not contain an 'ID' key, then a new user will be created and the new user's ID will be returned.</p> <p>If current user's password is being updated, then the cookies will be cleared.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>see</th> <td><a href="">\global\wp_insert_user()</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\wp_insert_user()</td> <code>int</code>The updated user's ID.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_upgrade"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_upgrade" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_upgrade .collapse"> <h2>Run WordPress Upgrade functions.</h2> <pre>wp_upgrade() : null</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p></p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.1.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"><code>null</code></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_upload_bits"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_upload_bits" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_upload_bits .collapse"> <h2>Create a file in the upload folder with given content.</h2> <pre>wp_upload_bits(string $name, null $deprecated, mixed $bits, string $time) : array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>If there is an error, then the key 'error' will exist with the error message. If success, then the key 'file' will have the unique file path, the 'url' key will have the link to the new file. and the 'error' key will be set to false.</p> <p>This function will not move an uploaded file to the upload folder. It will create a new file with the content in $bits parameter. If you move the upload file, read the content of the uploaded file, and then you can give the filename and content to this function, which will add it to the upload folder.</p> <p>The permissions will be set on the new file automatically by this function.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.0</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$name</h4> <code>string</code> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$deprecated</h4> <code>null</code><p>Never used. Set to null.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$bits</h4> <code>mixed</code><p>File content</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$time</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. Time formatted in 'yyyy/mm'.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"><code>array</code></div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_upload_dir"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_upload_dir" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_upload_dir .collapse"> <h2>Get an array containing the current upload directory's path and url.</h2> <pre>wp_upload_dir(string $time) : array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Checks the 'upload_path' option, which should be from the web root folder, and if it isn't empty it will be used. If it is empty, then the path will be 'WP_CONTENT_DIR/uploads'. If the 'UPLOADS' constant is defined, then it will override the 'upload_path' option and 'WP_CONTENT_DIR/uploads' path.</p> <p>The upload URL path is set either by the 'upload_url_path' option or by using the 'WP_CONTENT_URL' constant and appending '/uploads' to the path.</p> <p>If the 'uploads_use_yearmonth_folders' is set to true (checkbox if checked in the administration settings panel), then the time will be used. The format will be year first and then month.</p> <p>If the path couldn't be created, then an error will be returned with the key 'error' containing the error message. The error suggests that the parent directory is not writable by the server.</p> <p>On success, the returned array will have many indices: 'path' - base directory and sub directory or full path to upload directory. 'url' - base url and sub directory or absolute URL to upload directory. 'subdir' - sub directory if uploads use year/month folders option is on. 'basedir' - path without subdir. 'baseurl' - URL path without subdir. 'error' - set to false.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.0</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$time</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. Time formatted in 'yyyy/mm'.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>array</code>See above for description.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_user_settings"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_user_settings" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_user_settings .collapse"> <h2>Saves and restores user interface settings stored in a cookie.</h2> <pre>wp_user_settings() </pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Checks if the current user-settings cookie is updated and stores it. When no cookie exists (different browser used), adds the last saved cookie restoring the settings.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>package</th> <td><a href="../packages/WordPress.Option.html">WordPress</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th>subpackage</th> <td>Option</td> </tr> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.7.0</td> </tr> </table> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_validate_auth_cookie"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_validate_auth_cookie" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_validate_auth_cookie .collapse"> <h2>Validates authentication cookie.</h2> <pre>wp_validate_auth_cookie(string $cookie, string $scheme) : bool | int</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The checks include making sure that the authentication cookie is set and pulling in the contents (if $cookie is not used).</p> <p>Makes sure the cookie is not expired. Verifies the hash in cookie is what is should be and compares the two.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.5</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$cookie</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. If used, will validate contents instead of cookie's</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$scheme</h4> <code>string</code><p>Optional. The cookie scheme to use: auth, secure_auth, or logged_in</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>bool</code><code>int</code>False if invalid cookie, User ID if valid.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_validate_redirect"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wp_validate_redirect" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wp_validate_redirect .collapse"> <h2>Validates a URL for use in a redirect.</h2> <pre>wp_validate_redirect(string $location, string $default) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Checks whether the $location is using an allowed host, if it has an absolute path. A plugin can therefore set or remove allowed host(s) to or from the list.</p> <p>If the host is not allowed, then the redirect is to $default supplied</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.8.1</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\apply_filters()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$location</h4> <code>string</code><p>The redirect to validate</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$default</h4> <code>string</code><p>The value to return if $location is not allowed</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>redirect-sanitized URL</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wp_verify_nonce"></a><div class="element clickable function string | int $action) : bool</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>The user is given an amount of time to use the token, so therefore, since the UID and $action remain the same, the independent variable is the time.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>2.0.3</td> </tr></table> data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wpautop .collapse"> <h2>Replaces double line-breaks with paragraph elements.</h2> <pre>wpautop(string $pee, bool $br) : string</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>A group of regex replaces used to identify text formatted with newlines and replace double line-breaks with HTML paragraph tags. The remaining line-breaks after conversion become <<br />> tags, unless $br is set to '0' or 'false'.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"><tr> <th>since</th> <td>0.71</td> </tr></table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$pee</h4> <code>string</code><p>The text which has to be formatted.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$br</h4> <code>bool</code><p>Optional. If set, this will convert all remaining line-breaks after paragraphing. Default true.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>string</code>Text which has been converted into correct paragraph tags.</div> </div></div> </div> <a <pre>wpmu_create_blog(string $domain, string $path, string $title, int $user_id, array $meta, int $site_id) : mixed</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This function runs when a user self-registers a new site as well as when a Super Admin creates a new site. Hook to 'wpmu_new_blog' for events that should affect all new sites.</p> <p>On subdirectory installs, $domain is the same as the main site's domain, and the path is the subdirectory name (eg 'example.com' and '/blog1/'). On subdomain installs, $domain is the new subdomain + root domain (eg 'blog1.example.com'), and $path is '/'.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>MU</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\domain_exists()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\insert_blog()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\wp_install_defaults()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\add_user_to_blog()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$domain</h4> <code>string</code><p>The new site's domain.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$path</h4> <code>string</code><p>The new site's path.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$title</h4> <code>string</code><p>The new site's title.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$user_id</h4> <code>int</code><p>The user ID of the new site's admin.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$meta</h4> <code>array</code><p>Optional. Used to set initial site options.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$site_id</h4> <code>int</code><p>Optional. Only relevant on multi-network installs.</p> </div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>mixed</code>Returns WP_Error object on failure, int $blog_id on success</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wpmu_create_user"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wpmu_create_user" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wpmu_create_user .collapse"> <h2>Create a user.</h2> <pre>wpmu_create_user(string $user_name, string $password, string $email) : mixed</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>This function runs when a user self-registers as well as when a Super Admin creates a new user. notification function used when site registration is enabled.</p> <p>Filter 'wpmu_signup_blog_notification' to bypass this function or replace it with your own notification behavior.</p> <p>Filter 'wpmu_signup_blog_notification_email' and 'wpmu_signup_blog_notification_subject' to change the content and subject line of the email sent to newly registered users.</p></div> <table class="table address.</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$key</h4> <code>string</code><p>The activation key created in wpmu_signup_blog()</p> </div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$meta</h4> id="function_wpmu_validate_blog_signup"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wpmu_validate_blog_signup" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wpmu_validate_blog_signup .collapse"> <h2>Processes new site registrations.</h2> <pre>wpmu_validate_blog_signup(string $blogname, string $blog_title, $user) : array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Checks the data provided by the user during blog signup. Verifies the validity and uniqueness of blog paths and domains.</p> <p>This function prevents the current user from registering a new site with a blogname equivalent to another user's login name. Passing the $user parameter to the function, where $user is the other user, is effectively an override of this limitation.</p> <p>Filter 'wpmu_validate_blog_signup' if you want to modify the way that WordPress validates new site signups.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>MU</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\domain_exists()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\username_exists()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$blogname</h4> <code>string</code><p>The blog name provided by the user. Must be unique.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$blog_title</h4> <code>string</code><p>The blog title provided by the user.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"><h4>$user</h4></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>array</code>Contains the new site data and error messages.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wpmu_validate_user_signup"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wpmu_validate_user_signup" data-toggle="collapse" data-target=".function_wpmu_validate_user_signup .collapse"> <h2>Processes new user registrations.</h2> <pre>wpmu_validate_user_signup(string $user_name, string $user_email) : array</pre> <div class="labels"></div> <div class="row collapse"><div class="detail-description"> <div class="long_description"><p>Checks the data provided by the user during signup. Verifies the validity and uniqueness of user names and user email addresses, and checks email addresses against admin-provided domain whitelists and blacklists.</p> <p>The hook 'wpmu_validate_user_signup' provides an easy way to modify the signup process. The value $result, which is passed to the hook, contains both the user-provided info and the error messages created by the function. 'wpmu_validate_user_signup' allows you to process the data in any way you'd like, and unset the relevant errors if necessary.</p></div> <table class="table table-bordered"> <tr> <th>since</th> <td>MU</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\is_email_address_unsafe()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\username_exists()</td> </tr> <tr> <th>uses</th> <td>\global\email_exists()</td> </tr> </table> <h3>Parameters</h3> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$user_name</h4> <code>string</code><p>The login name provided by the user.</p></div> <div class="subelement argument"> <h4>$user_email</h4> <code>string</code><p>The email provided by the user.</p></div> <h3>Returns</h3> <div class="subelement response"> <code>array</code>Contains username, email, and error messages.</div> </div></div> </div> <a id="function_wpmu_welcome_notification"></a><div class="element clickable function function_wpmu_welcome_notification" data-toggle="collapse"
